 10318                       set_buffer_internal (XBUFFER (XWINDOW (window)->contents));
 10319                       goto replay_sequence;
 10320                     }
 10321                 }
 10322 
 10323               /* Expand mode-line and scroll-bar events into two events:
 10324                  use posn as a fake prefix key.  */
 10325               if (SYMBOLP (posn)
 10326                   && (NILP (fake_prefixed_keys)
 10327                       || NILP (Fmemq (key, fake_prefixed_keys))))
 10328                 {
 10329                   if (READ_KEY_ELTS - t <= 1)
 10330                     error ("Key sequence too long");
 10331 
 10332                   keybuf[t]     = posn;
 10333                   keybuf[t + 1] = key;
 10334                   mock_input    = t + 2;
 10335 
 10336                   /* Record that a fake prefix key has been generated
 10337                      for KEY.  Don't modify the event; this would
 10338                      prevent proper action when the event is pushed
 10339                      back into unread-command-events.  */
 10340                   fake_prefixed_keys = Fcons (key, fake_prefixed_keys);
 10341                   goto replay_key;
 10342                 }
 10343             }
 10344           else if (CONSP (XCDR (key))
 10345                    && CONSP (xevent_start (key))
 10346                    && CONSP (XCDR (xevent_start (key))))
 10347             {
 10348               Lisp_Object posn;
 10349 
 10350               posn = POSN_POSN (xevent_start (key));
 10351               /* Handle menu-bar events:
 10352                  insert the dummy prefix event `menu-bar'.  */
 10353               if (EQ (posn, Qmenu_bar) || EQ (posn, Qtab_bar) || EQ (posn, Qtool_bar))
 10354                 {
 10355                   if (READ_KEY_ELTS - t <= 1)
 10356                     error ("Key sequence too long");
 10357                   keybuf[t] = posn;
 10358                   keybuf[t + 1] = key;
 10359 
 10360                   /* Zap the position in key, so we know that we've
 10361                      expanded it, and don't try to do so again.  */
 10362                   POSN_SET_POSN (xevent_start (key), list1 (posn));
 10363 
 10364                   mock_input = t + 2;
 10365                   goto replay_sequence;
 10366                 }
 10367               else if (CONSP (posn))
 10368                 {
 10369                   /* We're looking at the second event of a
 10370                      sequence which we expanded before.  Set
 10371                      last_real_key_start appropriately.  */
 10372                   if (last_real_key_start == t && t > 0)
 10373                     last_real_key_start = t - 1;
 10374                 }
 10375             }
 10376         }
 10377 
 10378       /* We have finally decided that KEY is something we might want
 10379          to look up.  */
 10380       new_binding = follow_key (current_binding, key);
 10381 
 10382       /* If KEY wasn't bound, we'll try some fallbacks.  */
 10383       if (!NILP (new_binding))
 10384         /* This is needed for the following scenario:
 10385            event 0: a down-event that gets dropped by calling replay_key.
 10386            event 1: some normal prefix like C-h.
 10387            After event 0, first_unbound is 0, after event 1 indec.start,
 10388            fkey.start, and keytran.start are all 1, so when we see that
 10389            C-h is bound, we need to update first_unbound.  */
 10390         first_unbound = max (t + 1, first_unbound);
 10391       else
 10392         {
 10393           Lisp_Object head;
 10394 
 10395           /* Remember the position to put an upper bound on indec.start.  */
 10396           first_unbound = min (t, first_unbound);
 10397 
 10398           head = EVENT_HEAD (key);
 10399 
 10400           if (SYMBOLP (head))
 10401             {
 10402               Lisp_Object breakdown;
 10403               int modifiers;
 10404 
 10405               breakdown = parse_modifiers (head);
 10406               modifiers = XFIXNUM (XCAR (XCDR (breakdown)));
 10407               /* Attempt to reduce an unbound mouse event to a simpler
 10408                  event that is bound:
 10409                    Drags reduce to clicks.
 10410                    Double-clicks reduce to clicks.
 10411                    Triple-clicks reduce to double-clicks, then to clicks.
 10412                    Up/Down-clicks are eliminated.
 10413                    Double-downs reduce to downs, then are eliminated.
 10414                    Triple-downs reduce to double-downs, then to downs,
 10415                      then are eliminated.  */
 10416               if (modifiers & (up_modifier | down_modifier
 10417                                | drag_modifier
 10418                                | double_modifier | triple_modifier))
 10419                 {
 10420                   while (modifiers & (up_modifier | down_modifier
 10421                                       | drag_modifier
 10422                                       | double_modifier | triple_modifier))
 10423                     {
 10424                       Lisp_Object new_head, new_click;
 10425                       if (modifiers & triple_modifier)
 10426                         modifiers ^= (double_modifier | triple_modifier);
 10427                       else if (modifiers & double_modifier)
 10428                         modifiers &= ~double_modifier;
 10429                       else if (modifiers & drag_modifier)
 10430                         modifiers &= ~drag_modifier;
 10431                       else
 10432                         {
 10433                           /* Dispose of this `up/down' event by simply jumping
 10434                              back to replay_key, to get another event.
 10435 
 10436                              Note that if this event came from mock input,
 10437                              then just jumping back to replay_key will just
 10438                              hand it to us again.  So we have to wipe out any
 10439                              mock input.
 10440 
 10441                              We could delete keybuf[t] and shift everything
 10442                              after that to the left by one spot, but we'd also
 10443                              have to fix up any variable that points into
 10444                              keybuf, and shifting isn't really necessary
 10445                              anyway.
 10446 
 10447                              Adding prefixes for non-textual mouse clicks
 10448                              creates two characters of mock input, and both
 10449                              must be thrown away.  If we're only looking at
 10450                              the prefix now, we can just jump back to
 10451                              replay_key.  On the other hand, if we've already
 10452                              processed the prefix, and now the actual click
 10453                              itself is giving us trouble, then we've lost the
 10454                              state of the keymaps we want to backtrack to, and
 10455                              we need to replay the whole sequence to rebuild
 10456                              it.
 10457 
 10458                              Beyond that, only function key expansion could
 10459                              create more than two keys, but that should never
 10460                              generate mouse events, so it's okay to zero
 10461                              mock_input in that case too.
 10462 
 10463                              FIXME: The above paragraph seems just plain
 10464                              wrong, if you consider things like
 10465                              xterm-mouse-mode.  -stef
 10466 
 10467                              Isn't this just the most wonderful code ever?  */
 10468 
 10469                           /* If mock_input > t + 1, the above simplification
 10470                              will actually end up dropping keys on the floor.
 10471                              This is probably OK for now, but even
 10472                              if mock_input <= t + 1, we need to adjust indec,
 10473                              fkey, and keytran.
 10474                              Typical case [header-line down-mouse-N]:
 10475                              mock_input = 2, t = 1, fkey.end = 1,
 10476                              last_real_key_start = 0.  */
 10477                           if (indec.end > last_real_key_start)
 10478                             {
 10479                               indec.end = indec.start
 10480                                 = min (last_real_key_start, indec.start);
 10481                               indec.map = indec.parent;
 10482                               if (fkey.end > last_real_key_start)
 10483                                 {
 10484                                   fkey.end = fkey.start
 10485                                     = min (last_real_key_start, fkey.start);
 10486                                   fkey.map = fkey.parent;
 10487                                   if (keytran.end > last_real_key_start)
 10488                                     {
 10489                                       keytran.end = keytran.start
 10490                                         = min (last_real_key_start, keytran.start);
 10491                                       keytran.map = keytran.parent;
 10492                                     }
 10493                                 }
 10494                             }
 10495                           if (t == last_real_key_start)
 10496                             {
 10497                               mock_input = 0;
 10498                               goto replay_key;
 10499                             }
 10500                           else
 10501                             {
 10502                               mock_input = last_real_key_start;
 10503                               goto replay_sequence;
 10504                             }
 10505                         }
 10506 
 10507                       new_head
 10508                         = apply_modifiers (modifiers, XCAR (breakdown));
 10509                       new_click = list2 (new_head, EVENT_START (key));
 10510 
 10511                       /* Look for a binding for this new key.  */
 10512                       new_binding = follow_key (current_binding, new_click);
 10513 
 10514                       /* If that click is bound, go for it.  */
 10515                       if (!NILP (new_binding))
 10516                         {
 10517                           current_binding = new_binding;
 10518                           key = new_click;
 10519                           break;
 10520                         }
 10521                       /* Otherwise, we'll leave key set to the drag event.  */
 10522                     }
 10523                 }
 10524             }
 10525         }
 10526       current_binding = new_binding;
 10527 
 10528       keybuf[t++] = key;
 10529       /* Normally, last_nonmenu_event gets the previous key we read.
 10530          But when a mouse popup menu is being used,
 10531          we don't update last_nonmenu_event; it continues to hold the mouse
 10532          event that preceded the first level of menu.  */
 10533       if (!used_mouse_menu)
 10534         last_nonmenu_event = key;
 10535 
 10536       /* Record what part of this_command_keys is the current key sequence.  */
 10537       this_single_command_key_start = this_command_key_count - t;
 10538       /* When 'input-method-function' called above causes events to be
 10539          put on 'unread-post-input-method-events', and as result
 10540          'reread' is set to 'true', the value of 't' can become larger
 10541          than 'this_command_key_count', because 'add_command_key' is
 10542          not called to update 'this_command_key_count'.  If this
 10543          happens, 'this_single_command_key_start' will become negative
 10544          above, and any call to 'this-single-command-keys' will return
 10545          a garbled vector.  See bug #20223 for one such situation.
 10546          Here we force 'this_single_command_key_start' to never become
 10547          negative, to avoid that.  */
 10548       if (this_single_command_key_start < 0)
 10549         this_single_command_key_start = 0;
 10550 
 10551       /* Look for this sequence in input-decode-map.
 10552          Scan from indec.end until we find a bound suffix.  */
 10553       while (indec.end < t)
 10554         {
 10555           bool done;
 10556           int diff;
 10557 
 10558           done = keyremap_step (keybuf, &indec, max (t, mock_input),
 10559                                 true, &diff, prompt);
 10560           if (done)
 10561             {
 10562               mock_input = diff + max (t, mock_input);
 10563               goto replay_sequence;
 10564             }
 10565         }
 10566 
 10567       if (!KEYMAPP (current_binding)
 10568           && !test_undefined (current_binding)
 10569           && indec.start >= t)
 10570         /* There is a binding and it's not a prefix.
 10571            (and it doesn't have any input-decode-map translation pending).
 10572            There is thus no function-key in this sequence.
 10573            Moving fkey.start is important in this case to allow keytran.start
 10574            to go over the sequence before we return (since we keep the
 10575            invariant that keytran.end <= fkey.start).  */
 10576         {
 10577           if (fkey.start < t)
 10578             (fkey.start = fkey.end = t, fkey.map = fkey.parent);
 10579         }
 10580       else
 10581         /* If the sequence is unbound, see if we can hang a function key
 10582            off the end of it.  */
 10583         /* Continue scan from fkey.end until we find a bound suffix.  */
 10584         while (fkey.end < indec.start)
 10585           {
 10586             bool done;
 10587             int diff;
 10588 
 10589             done = keyremap_step (keybuf, &fkey,
 10590                                   max (t, mock_input),
 10591                                   /* If there's a binding (i.e.
 10592                                      first_binding >= nmaps) we don't want
 10593                                      to apply this function-key-mapping.  */
 10594                                   (fkey.end + 1 == t
 10595                                    && test_undefined (current_binding)),
 10596                                   &diff, prompt);
 10597             if (done)
 10598               {
 10599                 mock_input = diff + max (t, mock_input);
 10600                 /* Adjust the input-decode-map counters.  */
 10601                 indec.end += diff;
 10602                 indec.start += diff;
 10603 
 10604                 goto replay_sequence;
 10605               }
 10606           }
 10607 
 10608       /* Look for this sequence in key-translation-map.
 10609          Scan from keytran.end until we find a bound suffix.  */
 10610       while (keytran.end < fkey.start)
 10611         {
 10612           bool done;
 10613           int diff;
 10614 
 10615           done = keyremap_step (keybuf, &keytran, max (t, mock_input),
 10616                                 true, &diff, prompt);
 10617           if (done)
 10618             {
 10619               mock_input = diff + max (t, mock_input);
 10620               /* Adjust the function-key-map and input-decode-map counters.  */
 10621               indec.end += diff;
 10622               indec.start += diff;
 10623               fkey.end += diff;
 10624               fkey.start += diff;
 10625 
 10626               goto replay_sequence;
 10627             }
 10628         }
 10629 
 10630       /* If KEY is not defined in any of the keymaps,
 10631          and cannot be part of a function key or translation,
 10632          and is an upper case letter
 10633          use the corresponding lower-case letter instead.  */
 10634       if (NILP (current_binding)
 10635           && /* indec.start >= t && fkey.start >= t && */ keytran.start >= t
 10636           && FIXNUMP (key)
 10637           && translate_upper_case_key_bindings)
 10638         {
 10639           Lisp_Object new_key;
 10640           EMACS_INT k = XFIXNUM (key);
 10641 
 10642           if (k & shift_modifier)
 10643             XSETINT (new_key, k & ~shift_modifier);
 10644           else if (CHARACTERP (make_fixnum (k & ~CHAR_MODIFIER_MASK)))
 10645             {
 10646               int dc = downcase (k & ~CHAR_MODIFIER_MASK);
 10647               if (dc == (k & ~CHAR_MODIFIER_MASK))
 10648                 goto not_upcase;
 10649               XSETINT (new_key, dc | (k & CHAR_MODIFIER_MASK));
 10650             }
 10651           else
 10652             goto not_upcase;
 10653 
 10654           original_uppercase = key;
 10655           original_uppercase_position = t - 1;
 10656 
 10657           /* We have to do this unconditionally, regardless of whether
 10658              the lower-case char is defined in the keymaps, because they
 10659              might get translated through function-key-map.  */
 10660           keybuf[t - 1] = new_key;
 10661           mock_input = max (t, mock_input);
 10662           shift_translated = true;
 10663 
 10664           goto replay_sequence;
 10665         }
 10666 
 10667     not_upcase:
 10668       if (NILP (current_binding)
 10669           && help_char_p (EVENT_HEAD (key)) && t > 1)
 10670             {
 10671               read_key_sequence_cmd = Vprefix_help_command;
 10672               /* The Microsoft C compiler can't handle the goto that
 10673                  would go here.  */
 10674               dummyflag = true;
 10675               break;
 10676             }
 10677 
 10678       /* If KEY is not defined in any of the keymaps,
 10679          and cannot be part of a function key or translation,
 10680          and is a shifted function key,
 10681          use the corresponding unshifted function key instead.  */
 10682       if (NILP (current_binding)
 10683           && /* indec.start >= t && fkey.start >= t && */ keytran.start >= t)
 10684         {
 10685           Lisp_Object breakdown = parse_modifiers (key);
 10686           int modifiers
 10687             = CONSP (breakdown) ? (XFIXNUM (XCAR (XCDR (breakdown)))) : 0;
 10688 
 10689           if (translate_upper_case_key_bindings
 10690               && (modifiers & shift_modifier
 10691                   /* Treat uppercase keys as shifted.  */
 10692                   || (FIXNUMP (key)
 10693                       && (KEY_TO_CHAR (key)
 10694                           < XCHAR_TABLE (BVAR (current_buffer,
 10695                                                downcase_table))->header.size)
 10696                       && uppercasep (KEY_TO_CHAR (key)))))
 10697             {
 10698               Lisp_Object new_key
 10699                 = (modifiers & shift_modifier
 10700                    ? apply_modifiers (modifiers & ~shift_modifier,
 10701                                       XCAR (breakdown))
 10702                    : make_fixnum (downcase (KEY_TO_CHAR (key)) | modifiers));
 10703 
 10704               original_uppercase = key;
 10705               original_uppercase_position = t - 1;
 10706 
 10707               /* We have to do this unconditionally, regardless of whether
 10708                  the lower-case char is defined in the keymaps, because they
 10709                  might get translated through function-key-map.  */
 10710               keybuf[t - 1] = new_key;
 10711               mock_input = max (t, mock_input);
 10712               /* Reset fkey (and consequently keytran) to apply
 10713                  function-key-map on the result, so that S-backspace is
 10714                  correctly mapped to DEL (via backspace).  OTOH,
 10715                  input-decode-map doesn't need to go through it again.  */
 10716               fkey.start = fkey.end = 0;
 10717               keytran.start = keytran.end = 0;
 10718               shift_translated = true;
 10719 
 10720               goto replay_sequence;
 10721             }
 10722         }
 10723     }
 10724   if (!dummyflag)
 10725     read_key_sequence_cmd = current_binding;
 10726   read_key_sequence_remapped
 10727     /* Remap command through active keymaps.
 10728        Do the remapping here, before the unbind_to so it uses the keymaps
 10729        of the appropriate buffer.  */
 10730     = SYMBOLP (read_key_sequence_cmd)
 10731     ? Fcommand_remapping (read_key_sequence_cmd, Qnil, Qnil)
 10732     : Qnil;
 10733 
 10734   unread_switch_frame = delayed_switch_frame;
 10735   unbind_to (count, Qnil);
 10736 
 10737   /* Don't downcase the last character if the caller says don't.
 10738      Don't downcase it if the result is undefined, either.  */
 10739   if ((dont_downcase_last || NILP (current_binding))
 10740       && t > 0
 10741       && t - 1 == original_uppercase_position)
 10742     {
 10743       keybuf[t - 1] = original_uppercase;
 10744       shift_translated = false;
 10745     }
 10746 
 10747   if (shift_translated)
 10748     Vthis_command_keys_shift_translated = Qt;
 10749 
 10750   /* Occasionally we fabricate events, perhaps by expanding something
 10751      according to function-key-map, or by adding a prefix symbol to a
 10752      mouse click in the scroll bar or modeline.  In this cases, return
 10753      the entire generated key sequence, even if we hit an unbound
 10754      prefix or a definition before the end.  This means that you will
 10755      be able to push back the event properly, and also means that
 10756      read-key-sequence will always return a logical unit.
 10757 
 10758      Better ideas?  */
 10759   for (; t < mock_input; t++)
 10760     add_command_key (keybuf[t]);
 10761   echo_update ();
 10762 
 10763   return t;
 10764 }
 10765 
 10766 static Lisp_Object
 10767 read_key_sequence_vs (Lisp_Object prompt, Lisp_Object continue_echo,
 10768                       Lisp_Object dont_downcase_last,
 10769                       Lisp_Object can_return_switch_frame,
 10770                       Lisp_Object cmd_loop, bool allow_string)
 10771 {
 10772   specpdl_ref count = SPECPDL_INDEX ();
 10773 
 10774   if (!NILP (prompt))
 10775     CHECK_STRING (prompt);
 10776   maybe_quit ();
 10777 
 10778   specbind (Qinput_method_exit_on_first_char,
 10779             (NILP (cmd_loop) ? Qt : Qnil));
 10780   specbind (Qinput_method_use_echo_area,
 10781             (NILP (cmd_loop) ? Qt : Qnil));
 10782 
 10783   if (NILP (continue_echo))
 10784     {
 10785       this_command_key_count = 0;
 10786       this_single_command_key_start = 0;
 10787     }
 10788 
 10789 #ifdef HAVE_WINDOW_SYSTEM
 10790   if (display_hourglass_p)
 10791     cancel_hourglass ();
 10792 #endif
 10793 
 10794   raw_keybuf_count = 0;
 10795   Lisp_Object keybuf[READ_KEY_ELTS];
 10796   int i = read_key_sequence (keybuf, prompt, ! NILP (dont_downcase_last),
 10797                              ! NILP (can_return_switch_frame), false, false);
 10798 
 10799 #if 0  /* The following is fine for code reading a key sequence and
 10800           then proceeding with a lengthy computation, but it's not good
 10801           for code reading keys in a loop, like an input method.  */
 10802 #ifdef HAVE_WINDOW_SYSTEM
 10803   if (display_hourglass_p)
 10804     start_hourglass ();
 10805 #endif
 10806 #endif
 10807 
 10808   if (i == -1)
 10809     {
 10810       Vquit_flag = Qt;
 10811       maybe_quit ();
 10812     }
 10813 
 10814   return unbind_to (count,
 10815                     ((allow_string ? make_event_array : Fvector)
 10816                      (i, keybuf)));
 10817 }
 10818 
 10819 DEFUN ("read-key-sequence", Fread_key_sequence, Sread_key_sequence, 1, 5, 0,
 10820        doc: /* Read a sequence of keystrokes and return as a string or vector.
 10821 The sequence is sufficient to specify a non-prefix command in the
 10822 current local and global maps.
 10823 
 10824 First arg PROMPT is a prompt string.  If nil, do not prompt specially.
 10825 Second (optional) arg CONTINUE-ECHO, if non-nil, means this key echos
 10826 as a continuation of the previous key.
 10827 
 10828 The third (optional) arg DONT-DOWNCASE-LAST, if non-nil, means do not
 10829 convert the last event to lower case.  (Normally any upper case event
 10830 is converted to lower case if the original event is undefined and the lower
 10831 case equivalent is defined.)  A non-nil value is appropriate for reading
 10832 a key sequence to be defined.
 10833 
 10834 A C-g typed while in this function is treated like any other character,
 10835 and `quit-flag' is not set.
 10836 
 10837 If the key sequence starts with a mouse click, then the sequence is read
 10838 using the keymaps of the buffer of the window clicked in, not the buffer
 10839 of the selected window as normal.
 10840 
 10841 `read-key-sequence' drops unbound button-down events, since you normally
 10842 only care about the click or drag events which follow them.  If a drag
 10843 or multi-click event is unbound, but the corresponding click event would
 10844 be bound, `read-key-sequence' turns the event into a click event at the
 10845 drag's starting position.  This means that you don't have to distinguish
 10846 between click and drag, double, or triple events unless you want to.
 10847 
 10848 `read-key-sequence' prefixes mouse events on mode lines, the vertical
 10849 lines separating windows, and scroll bars with imaginary keys
 10850 `mode-line', `vertical-line', and `vertical-scroll-bar'.
 10851 
 10852 Optional fourth argument CAN-RETURN-SWITCH-FRAME non-nil means that this
 10853 function will process a switch-frame event if the user switches frames
 10854 before typing anything.  If the user switches frames in the middle of a
 10855 key sequence, or at the start of the sequence but CAN-RETURN-SWITCH-FRAME
 10856 is nil, then the event will be put off until after the current key sequence.
 10857 
 10858 `read-key-sequence' checks `function-key-map' for function key
 10859 sequences, where they wouldn't conflict with ordinary bindings.  See
 10860 `function-key-map' for more details.
 10861 
 10862 The optional fifth argument CMD-LOOP, if non-nil, means
 10863 that this key sequence is being read by something that will
 10864 read commands one after another.  It should be nil if the caller
 10865 will read just one key sequence.  */)
 10866   (Lisp_Object prompt, Lisp_Object continue_echo, Lisp_Object dont_downcase_last, Lisp_Object can_return_switch_frame, Lisp_Object cmd_loop)
 10867 {
 10868   return read_key_sequence_vs (prompt, continue_echo, dont_downcase_last,
 10869                                can_return_switch_frame, cmd_loop, true);
 10870 }
 10871 
 10872 DEFUN ("read-key-sequence-vector", Fread_key_sequence_vector,
 10873        Sread_key_sequence_vector, 1, 5, 0,
 10874        doc: /* Like `read-key-sequence' but always return a vector.  */)
 10875   (Lisp_Object prompt, Lisp_Object continue_echo, Lisp_Object dont_downcase_last, Lisp_Object can_return_switch_frame, Lisp_Object cmd_loop)
 10876 {
 10877   return read_key_sequence_vs (prompt, continue_echo, dont_downcase_last,
 10878                                can_return_switch_frame, cmd_loop, false);
 10879 }
 10880 
 10881 /* Return true if input events are pending.  */
 10882 
 10883 bool
 10884 detect_input_pending (void)
 10885 {
 10886   return input_pending || get_input_pending (0);
 10887 }
 10888 
 10889 /* Return true if input events other than mouse movements are
 10890    pending.  */
 10891 
 10892 bool
 10893 detect_input_pending_ignore_squeezables (void)
 10894 {
 10895   return input_pending || get_input_pending (READABLE_EVENTS_IGNORE_SQUEEZABLES);
 10896 }
 10897 
 10898 /* Return true if input events are pending, and run any pending timers.  */
 10899 
 10900 bool
 10901 detect_input_pending_run_timers (bool do_display)
 10902 {
 10903   unsigned old_timers_run = timers_run;
 10904 
 10905   if (!input_pending)
 10906     get_input_pending (READABLE_EVENTS_DO_TIMERS_NOW);
 10907 
 10908   if (old_timers_run != timers_run && do_display)
 10909     redisplay_preserve_echo_area (8);
 10910 
 10911   return input_pending;
 10912 }
 10913 
 10914 /* This is called in some cases before a possible quit.
 10915    It cases the next call to detect_input_pending to recompute input_pending.
 10916    So calling this function unnecessarily can't do any harm.  */
 10917 
 10918 void
 10919 clear_input_pending (void)
 10920 {
 10921   input_pending = false;
 10922 }
 10923 
 10924 /* Return true if there are pending requeued events.
 10925    This isn't used yet.  The hope is to make wait_reading_process_output
 10926    call it, and return if it runs Lisp code that unreads something.
 10927    The problem is, kbd_buffer_get_event needs to be fixed to know what
 10928    to do in that case.  It isn't trivial.  */
 10929 
 10930 bool
 10931 requeued_events_pending_p (void)
 10932 {
 10933   return (CONSP (Vunread_command_events));
 10934 }
 10935 
 10936 DEFUN ("input-pending-p", Finput_pending_p, Sinput_pending_p, 0, 1, 0,
 10937        doc: /* Return t if command input is currently available with no wait.
 10938 Actually, the value is nil only if we can be sure that no input is available;
 10939 if there is a doubt, the value is t.
 10940 
 10941 If CHECK-TIMERS is non-nil, timers that are ready to run will do so.  */)
 10942   (Lisp_Object check_timers)
 10943 {
 10944   if (CONSP (Vunread_command_events)
 10945       || !NILP (Vunread_post_input_method_events)
 10946       || !NILP (Vunread_input_method_events))
 10947     return (Qt);
 10948 
 10949   /* Process non-user-visible events (Bug#10195).  */
 10950   process_special_events ();
 10951 
 10952   return (get_input_pending ((NILP (check_timers)
 10953                               ? 0 : READABLE_EVENTS_DO_TIMERS_NOW)
 10954                              | READABLE_EVENTS_FILTER_EVENTS)
 10955           ? Qt : Qnil);
 10956 }
 10957 
 10958 /* Reallocate recent_keys copying the recorded keystrokes
 10959    in the right order.  */
 10960 static void
 10961 update_recent_keys (int new_size, int kept_keys)
 10962 {
 10963   int osize = ASIZE (recent_keys);
 10964   eassert (recent_keys_index < osize);
 10965   eassert (kept_keys <= min (osize, new_size));
 10966   Lisp_Object v = make_nil_vector (new_size);
 10967   int i, idx;
 10968   for (i = 0; i < kept_keys; ++i)
 10969     {
 10970       idx = recent_keys_index - kept_keys + i;
 10971       while (idx < 0)
 10972         idx += osize;
 10973       ASET (v, i, AREF (recent_keys, idx));
 10974     }
 10975   recent_keys = v;
 10976   total_keys = kept_keys;
 10977   recent_keys_index = total_keys % new_size;
 10978   lossage_limit = new_size;
 10979 
 10980 }
 10981 
 10982 DEFUN ("lossage-size", Flossage_size, Slossage_size, 0, 1,
 10983        "(list (read-number \"Set maximum keystrokes to: \" (lossage-size)))",
 10984        doc: /* Return or set the maximum number of keystrokes to save.
 10985 If called with a non-nil ARG, set the limit to ARG and return it.
 10986 Otherwise, return the current limit.
 10987 
 10988 The saved keystrokes are shown by `view-lossage'.  */)
 10989   (Lisp_Object arg)
 10990 {
 10991   if (NILP(arg))
 10992     return make_fixnum (lossage_limit);
 10993 
 10994   if (!FIXNATP (arg))
 10995     user_error ("Value must be a positive integer");
 10996   ptrdiff_t osize = ASIZE (recent_keys);
 10997   eassert (lossage_limit == osize);
 10998   int min_size = MIN_NUM_RECENT_KEYS;
 10999   EMACS_INT new_size = XFIXNAT (arg);
 11000 
 11001   if (new_size == osize)
 11002     return make_fixnum (lossage_limit);
 11003 
 11004   if (new_size < min_size)
 11005     {
 11006       AUTO_STRING (fmt, "Value must be >= %d");
 11007       Fsignal (Quser_error, list1 (CALLN (Fformat, fmt, make_fixnum (min_size))));
 11008     }
 11009   if (new_size > MAX_NUM_RECENT_KEYS)
 11010     {
 11011       AUTO_STRING (fmt, "Value must be <= %d");
 11012       Fsignal (Quser_error, list1 (CALLN (Fformat, fmt,
 11013                                           make_fixnum (MAX_NUM_RECENT_KEYS))));
 11014     }
 11015 
 11016   int kept_keys = new_size > osize ? total_keys : min (new_size, total_keys);
 11017   update_recent_keys (new_size, kept_keys);
 11018 
 11019   return make_fixnum (lossage_limit);
 11020 }
 11021 
 11022 DEFUN ("recent-keys", Frecent_keys, Srecent_keys, 0, 1, 0,
 11023        doc: /* Return vector of last few events, not counting those from keyboard macros.
 11024 If INCLUDE-CMDS is non-nil, include the commands that were run,
 11025 represented as pseudo-events of the form (nil . COMMAND).  */)
 11026   (Lisp_Object include_cmds)
 11027 {
 11028   bool cmds = !NILP (include_cmds);
 11029 
 11030   if (!total_keys
 11031       || (cmds && total_keys < lossage_limit))
 11032     return Fvector (total_keys,
 11033                     XVECTOR (recent_keys)->contents);
 11034   else
 11035     {
 11036       Lisp_Object es = Qnil;
 11037       int i = (total_keys < lossage_limit
 11038                ? 0 : recent_keys_index);
 11039       eassert (recent_keys_index < lossage_limit);
 11040       do
 11041         {
 11042           Lisp_Object e = AREF (recent_keys, i);
 11043           if (cmds || !CONSP (e) || !NILP (XCAR (e)))
 11044             es = Fcons (e, es);
 11045           if (++i >= lossage_limit)
 11046             i = 0;
 11047         } while (i != recent_keys_index);
 11048       es = Fnreverse (es);
 11049       return Fvconcat (1, &es);
 11050     }
 11051 }
 11052 
 11053 DEFUN ("this-command-keys", Fthis_command_keys, Sthis_command_keys, 0, 0, 0,
 11054        doc: /* Return the key sequence that invoked this command.
 11055 However, if the command has called `read-key-sequence', it returns
 11056 the last key sequence that has been read.
 11057 The value is a string or a vector.
 11058 
 11059 See also `this-command-keys-vector'.  */)
 11060   (void)
 11061 {
 11062   return make_event_array (this_command_key_count,
 11063                            XVECTOR (this_command_keys)->contents);
 11064 }
 11065 
 11066 DEFUN ("set--this-command-keys", Fset__this_command_keys,
 11067        Sset__this_command_keys, 1, 1, 0,
 11068        doc: /* Set the vector to be returned by `this-command-keys'.
 11069 The argument KEYS must be a string.
 11070 Internal use only.  */)
 11071   (Lisp_Object keys)
 11072 {
 11073   CHECK_STRING (keys);
 11074 
 11075   this_command_key_count = 0;
 11076   this_single_command_key_start = 0;
 11077 
 11078   ptrdiff_t charidx = 0, byteidx = 0;
 11079   int key0 = fetch_string_char_advance (keys, &charidx, &byteidx);
 11080   if (CHAR_BYTE8_P (key0))
 11081     key0 = CHAR_TO_BYTE8 (key0);
 11082 
 11083   /* Kludge alert: this makes M-x be in the form expected by
 11084      novice.el.  (248 is \370, a.k.a. "Meta-x".)  Any better ideas?  */
 11085   if (key0 == 248)
 11086     add_command_key (make_fixnum ('x' | meta_modifier));
 11087   else
 11088     add_command_key (make_fixnum (key0));
 11089   for (ptrdiff_t i = 1; i < SCHARS (keys); i++)
 11090     {
 11091       int key_i = fetch_string_char_advance (keys, &charidx, &byteidx);
 11092       if (CHAR_BYTE8_P (key_i))
 11093         key_i = CHAR_TO_BYTE8 (key_i);
 11094       add_command_key (make_fixnum (key_i));
 11095     }
 11096   return Qnil;
 11097 }
 11098 
 11099 DEFUN ("this-command-keys-vector", Fthis_command_keys_vector, Sthis_command_keys_vector, 0, 0, 0,
 11100        doc: /* Return the key sequence that invoked this command, as a vector.
 11101 However, if the command has called `read-key-sequence', it returns
 11102 the last key sequence that has been read.
 11103 
 11104 See also `this-command-keys'.  */)
 11105   (void)
 11106 {
 11107   return Fvector (this_command_key_count,
 11108                   XVECTOR (this_command_keys)->contents);
 11109 }
 11110 
 11111 DEFUN ("this-single-command-keys", Fthis_single_command_keys,
 11112        Sthis_single_command_keys, 0, 0, 0,
 11113        doc: /* Return the key sequence that invoked this command.
 11114 More generally, it returns the last key sequence read, either by
 11115 the command loop or by `read-key-sequence'.
 11116 The value is always a vector.  */)
 11117   (void)
 11118 {
 11119   return Fvector (this_command_key_count
 11120                   - this_single_command_key_start,
 11121                   (XVECTOR (this_command_keys)->contents
 11122                    + this_single_command_key_start));
 11123 }
 11124 
 11125 DEFUN ("this-single-command-raw-keys", Fthis_single_command_raw_keys,
 11126        Sthis_single_command_raw_keys, 0, 0, 0,
 11127        doc: /* Return the raw events that were read for this command.
 11128 More generally, it returns the last key sequence read, either by
 11129 the command loop or by `read-key-sequence'.
 11130 Unlike `this-single-command-keys', this function's value
 11131 shows the events before all translations (except for input methods).
 11132 The value is always a vector.  */)
 11133   (void)
 11134 {
 11135   return Fvector (raw_keybuf_count, XVECTOR (raw_keybuf)->contents);
 11136 }
 11137 
 11138 DEFUN ("clear-this-command-keys", Fclear_this_command_keys,
 11139        Sclear_this_command_keys, 0, 1, 0,
 11140        doc: /* Clear out the vector that `this-command-keys' returns.
 11141 Also clear the record of the last 300 input events, unless optional arg
 11142 KEEP-RECORD is non-nil.  */)
 11143   (Lisp_Object keep_record)
 11144 {
 11145   int i;
 11146 
 11147   this_command_key_count = 0;
 11148 
 11149   if (NILP (keep_record))
 11150     {
 11151       for (i = 0; i < ASIZE (recent_keys); ++i)
 11152         ASET (recent_keys, i, Qnil);
 11153       total_keys = 0;
 11154       recent_keys_index = 0;
 11155     }
 11156   return Qnil;
 11157 }
 11158 
 11159 DEFUN ("recursion-depth", Frecursion_depth, Srecursion_depth, 0, 0, 0,
 11160        doc: /* Return the current depth in recursive edits.  */)
 11161   (void)
 11162 {
 11163   EMACS_INT sum;
 11164   INT_ADD_WRAPV (command_loop_level, minibuf_level, &sum);
 11165   return make_fixnum (sum);
 11166 }
 11167 
 11168 DEFUN ("open-dribble-file", Fopen_dribble_file, Sopen_dribble_file, 1, 1,
 11169        "FOpen dribble file: ",
 11170        doc: /* Start writing input events to a dribble file called FILE.
 11171 Any previously open dribble file will be closed first.  If FILE is
 11172 nil, just close the dribble file, if any.
 11173 
 11174 If the file is still open when Emacs exits, it will be closed then.
 11175 
 11176 The events written to the file include keyboard and mouse input
 11177 events, but not events from executing keyboard macros.  The events are
 11178 written to the dribble file immediately without line buffering.
 11179 
 11180 Be aware that this records ALL characters you type!
 11181 This may include sensitive information such as passwords.  */)
 11182   (Lisp_Object file)
 11183 {
 11184   if (dribble)
 11185     {
 11186       block_input ();
 11187       fclose (dribble);
 11188       unblock_input ();
 11189       dribble = 0;
 11190     }
 11191   if (!NILP (file))
 11192     {
 11193       int fd;
 11194       Lisp_Object encfile;
 11195 
 11196       file = Fexpand_file_name (file, Qnil);
 11197       encfile = ENCODE_FILE (file);
 11198       fd = emacs_open (SSDATA (encfile), O_WRONLY | O_CREAT | O_EXCL, 0600);
 11199       if (fd < 0 && errno == EEXIST
 11200           && (unlink (SSDATA (encfile)) == 0 || errno == ENOENT))
 11201         fd = emacs_open (SSDATA (encfile), O_WRONLY | O_CREAT | O_EXCL, 0600);
 11202       dribble = fd < 0 ? 0 : fdopen (fd, "w");
 11203       if (dribble == 0)
 11204         report_file_error ("Opening dribble", file);
 11205     }
 11206   return Qnil;
 11207 }
 11208 
 11209 DEFUN ("discard-input", Fdiscard_input, Sdiscard_input, 0, 0, 0,
 11210        doc: /* Discard the contents of the terminal input buffer.
 11211 Also end any kbd macro being defined.  */)
 11212   (void)
 11213 {
 11214   if (!NILP (KVAR (current_kboard, defining_kbd_macro)))
 11215     {
 11216       /* Discard the last command from the macro.  */
 11217       Fcancel_kbd_macro_events ();
 11218       end_kbd_macro ();
 11219     }
 11220 
 11221   Vunread_command_events = Qnil;
 11222 
 11223   discard_tty_input ();
 11224 
 11225   kbd_fetch_ptr =  kbd_store_ptr;
 11226   input_pending = false;
 11227 
 11228   return Qnil;
 11229 }
 11230 
 11231 DEFUN ("suspend-emacs", Fsuspend_emacs, Ssuspend_emacs, 0, 1, "",
 11232        doc: /* Stop Emacs and return to superior process.  You can resume later.
 11233 If `cannot-suspend' is non-nil, or if the system doesn't support job
 11234 control, run a subshell instead.
 11235 
 11236 If optional arg STUFFSTRING is non-nil, its characters are stuffed
 11237 to be read as terminal input by Emacs's parent, after suspension.
 11238 
 11239 Before suspending, run the normal hook `suspend-hook'.
 11240 After resumption run the normal hook `suspend-resume-hook'.
 11241 
 11242 Some operating systems cannot stop the Emacs process and resume it later.
 11243 On such systems, Emacs starts a subshell instead of suspending.  */)
 11244   (Lisp_Object stuffstring)
 11245 {
 11246   specpdl_ref count = SPECPDL_INDEX ();
 11247   int old_height, old_width;
 11248   int width, height;
 11249 
 11250   if (tty_list && tty_list->next)
 11251     error ("There are other tty frames open; close them before suspending Emacs");
 11252 
 11253   if (!NILP (stuffstring))
 11254     CHECK_STRING (stuffstring);
 11255 
 11256   run_hook (intern ("suspend-hook"));
 11257 
 11258   get_tty_size (fileno (CURTTY ()->input), &old_width, &old_height);
 11259   reset_all_sys_modes ();
 11260   /* sys_suspend can get an error if it tries to fork a subshell
 11261      and the system resources aren't available for that.  */
 11262   record_unwind_protect_void (init_all_sys_modes);
 11263   stuff_buffered_input (stuffstring);
 11264   if (cannot_suspend)
 11265     sys_subshell ();
 11266   else
 11267     sys_suspend ();
 11268   unbind_to (count, Qnil);
 11269 
 11270   /* Check if terminal/window size has changed.
 11271      Note that this is not useful when we are running directly
 11272      with a window system; but suspend should be disabled in that case.  */
 11273   get_tty_size (fileno (CURTTY ()->input), &width, &height);
 11274   if (width != old_width || height != old_height)
 11275     change_frame_size (SELECTED_FRAME (), width, height, false, false, false);
 11276 
 11277   run_hook (intern ("suspend-resume-hook"));
 11278 
 11279   return Qnil;
 11280 }
 11281 
 11282 /* If STUFFSTRING is a string, stuff its contents as pending terminal input.
 11283    Then in any case stuff anything Emacs has read ahead and not used.  */
 11284 
 11285 void
 11286 stuff_buffered_input (Lisp_Object stuffstring)
 11287 {
 11288 #ifdef SIGTSTP  /* stuff_char is defined if SIGTSTP.  */
 11289   register unsigned char *p;
 11290 
 11291   if (STRINGP (stuffstring))
 11292     {
 11293       register ptrdiff_t count;
 11294 
 11295       p = SDATA (stuffstring);
 11296       count = SBYTES (stuffstring);
 11297       while (count-- > 0)
 11298         stuff_char (*p++);
 11299       stuff_char ('\n');
 11300     }
 11301 
 11302   /* Anything we have read ahead, put back for the shell to read.  */
 11303   /* ?? What should this do when we have multiple keyboards??
 11304      Should we ignore anything that was typed in at the "wrong" kboard?
 11305 
 11306      rms: we should stuff everything back into the kboard
 11307      it came from.  */
 11308   for (; kbd_fetch_ptr != kbd_store_ptr;
 11309        kbd_fetch_ptr = next_kbd_event (kbd_fetch_ptr))
 11310     {
 11311 
 11312       if (kbd_fetch_ptr->kind == ASCII_KEYSTROKE_EVENT)
 11313         stuff_char (kbd_fetch_ptr->ie.code);
 11314 
 11315       clear_event (&kbd_fetch_ptr->ie);
 11316     }
 11317 
 11318   input_pending = false;
 11319 #endif /* SIGTSTP */
 11320 }
 11321 
 11322 void
 11323 set_waiting_for_input (struct timespec *time_to_clear)
 11324 {
 11325   input_available_clear_time = time_to_clear;
 11326 
 11327   /* Tell handle_interrupt to throw back to read_char,  */
 11328   waiting_for_input = true;
 11329 
 11330   /* If handle_interrupt was called before and buffered a C-g,
 11331      make it run again now, to avoid timing error.  */
 11332   if (!NILP (Vquit_flag))
 11333     quit_throw_to_read_char (0);
 11334 }
 11335 
 11336 void
 11337 clear_waiting_for_input (void)
 11338 {
 11339   /* Tell handle_interrupt not to throw back to read_char,  */
 11340   waiting_for_input = false;
 11341   input_available_clear_time = 0;
 11342 }
 11343 
 11344 /* The SIGINT handler.
 11345 
 11346    If we have a frame on the controlling tty, we assume that the
 11347    SIGINT was generated by C-g, so we call handle_interrupt.
 11348    Otherwise, tell maybe_quit to kill Emacs.  */
 11349 
 11350 static void
 11351 handle_interrupt_signal (int sig)
 11352 {
 11353   /* See if we have an active terminal on our controlling tty.  */
 11354   struct terminal *terminal = get_named_terminal (DEV_TTY);
 11355   if (!terminal)
 11356     {
 11357       /* If there are no frames there, let's pretend that we are a
 11358          well-behaving UN*X program and quit.  We must not call Lisp
 11359          in a signal handler, so tell maybe_quit to exit when it is
 11360          safe.  */
 11361       Vquit_flag = Qkill_emacs;
 11362     }
 11363   else
 11364     {
 11365       /* Otherwise, the SIGINT was probably generated by C-g.  */
 11366 
 11367       /* Set internal_last_event_frame to the top frame of the
 11368          controlling tty, if we have a frame there.  We disable the
 11369          interrupt key on secondary ttys, so the SIGINT must have come
 11370          from the controlling tty.  */
 11371       internal_last_event_frame = terminal->display_info.tty->top_frame;
 11372 
 11373       handle_interrupt (1);
 11374     }
 11375 }
 11376 
 11377 static void
 11378 deliver_interrupt_signal (int sig)
 11379 {
 11380   deliver_process_signal (sig, handle_interrupt_signal);
 11381 }
 11382 
 11383 /* Output MSG directly to standard output, without buffering.  Ignore
 11384    failures.  This is safe in a signal handler.  */
 11385 static void
 11386 write_stdout (char const *msg)
 11387 {
 11388   ignore_value (write (STDOUT_FILENO, msg, strlen (msg)));
 11389 }
 11390 
 11391 /* Read a byte from stdin, without buffering.  Safe in signal handlers.  */
 11392 static int
 11393 read_stdin (void)
 11394 {
 11395   char c;
 11396   return read (STDIN_FILENO, &c, 1) == 1 ? c : EOF;
 11397 }
 11398 
 11399 /* If Emacs is stuck because `inhibit-quit' is true, then keep track
 11400    of the number of times C-g has been requested.  If C-g is pressed
 11401    enough times, then quit anyway.  See bug#6585.  */
 11402 static int volatile force_quit_count;
 11403 
 11404 /* This routine is called at interrupt level in response to C-g.
 11405 
 11406    It is called from the SIGINT handler or kbd_buffer_store_event.
 11407 
 11408    If `waiting_for_input' is non zero, then unless `echoing' is
 11409    nonzero, immediately throw back to read_char.
 11410 
 11411    Otherwise it sets the Lisp variable quit-flag not-nil.  This causes
 11412    eval to throw, when it gets a chance.  If quit-flag is already
 11413    non-nil, it stops the job right away.  */
 11414 
 11415 static void
 11416 handle_interrupt (bool in_signal_handler)
 11417 {
 11418   char c;
 11419 
 11420   cancel_echoing ();
 11421 
 11422   /* XXX This code needs to be revised for multi-tty support.  */
 11423   if (!NILP (Vquit_flag) && get_named_terminal (DEV_TTY))
 11424     {
 11425       if (! in_signal_handler)
 11426         {
 11427           /* If SIGINT isn't blocked, don't let us be interrupted by
 11428              a SIGINT.  It might be harmful due to non-reentrancy
 11429              in I/O functions.  */
 11430           sigset_t blocked;
 11431           sigemptyset (&blocked);
 11432           sigaddset (&blocked, SIGINT);
 11433           pthread_sigmask (SIG_BLOCK, &blocked, 0);
 11434           fflush (stdout);
 11435         }
 11436 
 11437       reset_all_sys_modes ();
 11438 
 11439 #ifdef SIGTSTP
 11440 /*
 11441  * On systems which can suspend the current process and return to the original
 11442  * shell, this command causes the user to end up back at the shell.
 11443  * The "Auto-save" and "Abort" questions are not asked until
 11444  * the user elects to return to emacs, at which point he can save the current
 11445  * job and either dump core or continue.
 11446  */
 11447       sys_suspend ();
 11448 #else
 11449       /* Perhaps should really fork an inferior shell?
 11450          But that would not provide any way to get back
 11451          to the original shell, ever.  */
 11452       write_stdout ("No support for stopping a process"
 11453                     " on this operating system;\n"
 11454                     "you can continue or abort.\n");
 11455 #endif /* not SIGTSTP */
 11456 #ifdef MSDOS
 11457       /* We must remain inside the screen area when the internal terminal
 11458          is used.  Note that [Enter] is not echoed by dos.  */
 11459       cursor_to (SELECTED_FRAME (), 0, 0);
 11460 #endif
 11461 
 11462       write_stdout ("Emacs is resuming after an emergency escape.\n");
 11463 
 11464       /* It doesn't work to autosave while GC is in progress;
 11465          the code used for auto-saving doesn't cope with the mark bit.  */
 11466       if (!gc_in_progress)
 11467         {
 11468           write_stdout ("Auto-save? (y or n) ");
 11469           c = read_stdin ();
 11470           if (c == 'y' || c == 'Y')
 11471             {
 11472               Fdo_auto_save (Qt, Qnil);
 11473 #ifdef MSDOS
 11474               write_stdout ("\r\nAuto-save done");
 11475 #else
 11476               write_stdout ("Auto-save done\n");
 11477 #endif
 11478             }
 11479           while (c != '\n')
 11480             c = read_stdin ();
 11481         }
 11482       else
 11483         {
 11484           /* During GC, it must be safe to reenable quitting again.  */
 11485           Vinhibit_quit = Qnil;
 11486           write_stdout
 11487             (
 11488 #ifdef MSDOS
 11489              "\r\n"
 11490 #endif
 11491              "Garbage collection in progress; cannot auto-save now\r\n"
 11492              "but will instead do a real quit"
 11493              " after garbage collection ends\r\n");
 11494         }
 11495 
 11496 #ifdef MSDOS
 11497       write_stdout ("\r\nAbort?  (y or n) ");
 11498 #else
 11499       write_stdout ("Abort (and dump core)? (y or n) ");
 11500 #endif
 11501       c = read_stdin ();
 11502       if (c == 'y' || c == 'Y')
 11503         emacs_abort ();
 11504       while (c != '\n')
 11505         c = read_stdin ();
 11506 #ifdef MSDOS
 11507       write_stdout ("\r\nContinuing...\r\n");
 11508 #else /* not MSDOS */
 11509       write_stdout ("Continuing...\n");
 11510 #endif /* not MSDOS */
 11511       init_all_sys_modes ();
 11512     }
 11513   else
 11514     {
 11515       /* Request quit when it's safe.  */
 11516       int count = NILP (Vquit_flag) ? 1 : force_quit_count + 1;
 11517       force_quit_count = count;
 11518       if (count == 3)
 11519         Vinhibit_quit = Qnil;
 11520       Vquit_flag = Qt;
 11521     }
 11522 
 11523   pthread_sigmask (SIG_SETMASK, &empty_mask, 0);
 11524 
 11525 /* TODO: The longjmp in this call throws the NS event loop integration off,
 11526          and it seems to do fine without this.  Probably some attention
 11527          needs to be paid to the setting of waiting_for_input in
 11528          wait_reading_process_output() under HAVE_NS because of the call
 11529          to ns_select there (needed because otherwise events aren't picked up
 11530          outside of polling since we don't get SIGIO like X and we don't have a
 11531          separate event loop thread like W32.  */
 11532 #ifndef HAVE_NS
 11533 #ifdef THREADS_ENABLED
 11534   /* If we were called from a signal handler, we must be in the main
 11535      thread, see deliver_process_signal.  So we must make sure the
 11536      main thread holds the global lock.  */
 11537   if (in_signal_handler)
 11538     maybe_reacquire_global_lock ();
 11539 #endif
 11540   if (waiting_for_input && !echoing)
 11541     quit_throw_to_read_char (in_signal_handler);
 11542 #endif
 11543 }
 11544 
 11545 /* Handle a C-g by making read_char return C-g.  */
 11546 
 11547 static void
 11548 quit_throw_to_read_char (bool from_signal)
 11549 {
 11550   /* When not called from a signal handler it is safe to call
 11551      Lisp.  */
 11552   if (!from_signal && EQ (Vquit_flag, Qkill_emacs))
 11553     Fkill_emacs (Qnil, Qnil);
 11554 
 11555   /* Prevent another signal from doing this before we finish.  */
 11556   clear_waiting_for_input ();
 11557   input_pending = false;
 11558 
 11559   Vunread_command_events = Qnil;
 11560 
 11561   if (FRAMEP (internal_last_event_frame)
 11562       && !EQ (internal_last_event_frame, selected_frame))
 11563     do_switch_frame (make_lispy_switch_frame (internal_last_event_frame),
 11564                      0, 0, Qnil);
 11565 
 11566   sys_longjmp (getcjmp, 1);
 11567 }
 11568 
 11569 DEFUN ("set-input-interrupt-mode", Fset_input_interrupt_mode,
 11570        Sset_input_interrupt_mode, 1, 1, 0,
 11571        doc: /* Set interrupt mode of reading keyboard input.
 11572 If INTERRUPT is non-nil, Emacs will use input interrupts;
 11573 otherwise Emacs uses CBREAK mode.
 11574 
 11575 See also `current-input-mode'.  */)
 11576   (Lisp_Object interrupt)
 11577 {
 11578   bool new_interrupt_input;
 11579 #if defined (USABLE_SIGIO) || defined (USABLE_SIGPOLL)
 11580 #ifdef HAVE_X_WINDOWS
 11581   if (x_display_list != NULL)
 11582     {
 11583       /* When using X, don't give the user a real choice,
 11584          because we haven't implemented the mechanisms to support it.  */
 11585       new_interrupt_input = true;
 11586     }
 11587   else
 11588 #endif /* HAVE_X_WINDOWS */
 11589     new_interrupt_input = !NILP (interrupt);
 11590 #else /* not USABLE_SIGIO || USABLE_SIGPOLL */
 11591   new_interrupt_input = false;
 11592 #endif /* not USABLE_SIGIO || USABLE_SIGPOLL */
 11593 
 11594   if (new_interrupt_input != interrupt_input)
 11595     {
 11596 #ifdef POLL_FOR_INPUT
 11597       stop_polling ();
 11598 #endif
 11599 #ifndef DOS_NT
 11600       /* this causes startup screen to be restored and messes with the mouse */
 11601       reset_all_sys_modes ();
 11602       interrupt_input = new_interrupt_input;
 11603       init_all_sys_modes ();
 11604 #else
 11605       interrupt_input = new_interrupt_input;
 11606 #endif
 11607 
 11608 #ifdef POLL_FOR_INPUT
 11609       poll_suppress_count = 1;
 11610       start_polling ();
 11611 #endif
 11612     }
 11613   return Qnil;
 11614 }
 11615 
 11616 DEFUN ("set-output-flow-control", Fset_output_flow_control, Sset_output_flow_control, 1, 2, 0,
 11617        doc: /* Enable or disable ^S/^Q flow control for output to TERMINAL.
 11618 If FLOW is non-nil, flow control is enabled and you cannot use C-s or
 11619 C-q in key sequences.
 11620 
 11621 This setting only has an effect on tty terminals and only when
 11622 Emacs reads input in CBREAK mode; see `set-input-interrupt-mode'.
 11623 
 11624 See also `current-input-mode'.  */)
 11625   (Lisp_Object flow, Lisp_Object terminal)
 11626 {
 11627   struct terminal *t = decode_tty_terminal (terminal);
 11628   struct tty_display_info *tty;
 11629 
 11630   if (!t)
 11631     return Qnil;
 11632   tty = t->display_info.tty;
 11633 
 11634   if (tty->flow_control != !NILP (flow))
 11635     {
 11636 #ifndef DOS_NT
 11637       /* This causes startup screen to be restored and messes with the mouse.  */
 11638       reset_sys_modes (tty);
 11639 #endif
 11640 
 11641       tty->flow_control = !NILP (flow);
 11642 
 11643 #ifndef DOS_NT
 11644       init_sys_modes (tty);
 11645 #endif
 11646     }
 11647   return Qnil;
 11648 }
 11649 
 11650 DEFUN ("set-input-meta-mode", Fset_input_meta_mode, Sset_input_meta_mode, 1, 2, 0,
 11651        doc: /* Enable or disable 8-bit input on TERMINAL.
 11652 If META is t, Emacs will accept 8-bit input, and interpret the 8th
 11653 bit as the Meta modifier before it decodes the characters.
 11654 
 11655 If META is `encoded', Emacs will interpret the 8th bit of single-byte
 11656 characters after decoding the characters.
 11657 
 11658 If META is nil, Emacs will ignore the top bit, on the assumption it is
 11659 parity.
 11660 
 11661 Otherwise, Emacs will accept and pass through 8-bit input without
 11662 specially interpreting the top bit.
 11663 
 11664 This setting only has an effect on tty terminal devices.
 11665 
 11666 Optional parameter TERMINAL specifies the tty terminal device to use.
 11667 It may be a terminal object, a frame, or nil for the terminal used by
 11668 the currently selected frame.
 11669 
 11670 See also `current-input-mode'.  */)
 11671   (Lisp_Object meta, Lisp_Object terminal)
 11672 {
 11673   struct terminal *t = decode_tty_terminal (terminal);
 11674   struct tty_display_info *tty;
 11675   int new_meta;
 11676 
 11677   if (!t)
 11678     return Qnil;
 11679   tty = t->display_info.tty;
 11680 
 11681   if (NILP (meta))
 11682     new_meta = 0;
 11683   else if (EQ (meta, Qt))
 11684     new_meta = 1;
 11685   else if (EQ (meta, Qencoded))
 11686     new_meta = 3;
 11687   else
 11688     new_meta = 2;
 11689 
 11690   if (tty->meta_key != new_meta)
 11691     {
 11692 #ifndef DOS_NT
 11693       /* this causes startup screen to be restored and messes with the mouse */
 11694       reset_sys_modes (tty);
 11695 #endif
 11696 
 11697       tty->meta_key = new_meta;
 11698 
 11699 #ifndef DOS_NT
 11700       init_sys_modes (tty);
 11701 #endif
 11702     }
 11703   return Qnil;
 11704 }
 11705 
 11706 DEFUN ("set-quit-char", Fset_quit_char, Sset_quit_char, 1, 1, 0,
 11707        doc: /* Specify character used for quitting.
 11708 QUIT must be an ASCII character.
 11709 
 11710 This function only has an effect on the controlling tty of the Emacs
 11711 process.
 11712 
 11713 See also `current-input-mode'.  */)
 11714   (Lisp_Object quit)
 11715 {
 11716   struct terminal *t = get_named_terminal (DEV_TTY);
 11717   struct tty_display_info *tty;
 11718 
 11719   if (!t)
 11720     return Qnil;
 11721   tty = t->display_info.tty;
 11722 
 11723   if (NILP (quit) || !FIXNUMP (quit) || XFIXNUM (quit) < 0 || XFIXNUM (quit) > 0400)
 11724     error ("QUIT must be an ASCII character");
 11725 
 11726 #ifndef DOS_NT
 11727   /* this causes startup screen to be restored and messes with the mouse */
 11728   reset_sys_modes (tty);
 11729 #endif
 11730 
 11731   /* Don't let this value be out of range.  */
 11732   quit_char = XFIXNUM (quit) & (tty->meta_key == 0 ? 0177 : 0377);
 11733 
 11734 #ifndef DOS_NT
 11735   init_sys_modes (tty);
 11736 #endif
 11737 
 11738   return Qnil;
 11739 }
 11740 
 11741 DEFUN ("set-input-mode", Fset_input_mode, Sset_input_mode, 3, 4, 0,
 11742        doc: /* Set mode of reading keyboard input.
 11743 First arg INTERRUPT non-nil means use input interrupts;
 11744  nil means use CBREAK mode.
 11745 Second arg FLOW non-nil means use ^S/^Q flow control for output to terminal
 11746  (no effect except in CBREAK mode).
 11747 Third arg META t means accept 8-bit input (for a Meta key).
 11748  META nil means ignore the top bit, on the assumption it is parity.
 11749  META `encoded' means accept 8-bit input and interpret Meta after
 11750    decoding the input characters.
 11751  Otherwise, accept 8-bit input and don't use the top bit for Meta.
 11752 Optional fourth arg QUIT if non-nil specifies character to use for quitting.
 11753 See also `current-input-mode'.  */)
 11754   (Lisp_Object interrupt, Lisp_Object flow, Lisp_Object meta, Lisp_Object quit)
 11755 {
 11756   Fset_input_interrupt_mode (interrupt);
 11757   Fset_output_flow_control (flow, Qnil);
 11758   Fset_input_meta_mode (meta, Qnil);
 11759   if (!NILP (quit))
 11760     Fset_quit_char (quit);
 11761   return Qnil;
 11762 }
 11763 
 11764 DEFUN ("current-input-mode", Fcurrent_input_mode, Scurrent_input_mode, 0, 0, 0,
 11765        doc: /* Return information about the way Emacs currently reads keyboard input.
 11766 The value is a list of the form (INTERRUPT FLOW META QUIT), where
 11767   INTERRUPT is non-nil if Emacs is using interrupt-driven input; if
 11768     nil, Emacs is using CBREAK mode.
 11769   FLOW is non-nil if Emacs uses ^S/^Q flow control for output to the
 11770     terminal; this does not apply if Emacs uses interrupt-driven input.
 11771   META is t if accepting 8-bit unencoded input with 8th bit as Meta flag.
 11772   META is `encoded' if accepting 8-bit encoded input with 8th bit as
 11773     Meta flag which has to be interpreted after decoding the input.
 11774   META is nil if ignoring the top bit of input, on the assumption that
 11775     it is a parity bit.
 11776   META is neither t nor nil if accepting 8-bit input and using
 11777     all 8 bits as the character code.
 11778   QUIT is the character Emacs currently uses to quit.
 11779 The elements of this list correspond to the arguments of
 11780 `set-input-mode'.  */)
 11781   (void)
 11782 {
 11783   struct frame *sf = XFRAME (selected_frame);
 11784 
 11785   Lisp_Object interrupt = interrupt_input ? Qt : Qnil;
 11786   Lisp_Object flow, meta;
 11787   if (FRAME_TERMCAP_P (sf) || FRAME_MSDOS_P (sf))
 11788     {
 11789       flow = FRAME_TTY (sf)->flow_control ? Qt : Qnil;
 11790       meta = (FRAME_TTY (sf)->meta_key == 2
 11791               ? make_fixnum (0)
 11792               : (CURTTY ()->meta_key == 1
 11793                  ? Qt
 11794                  : (CURTTY ()->meta_key == 3 ? Qencoded : Qnil)));
 11795     }
 11796   else
 11797     {
 11798       flow = Qnil;
 11799       meta = Qt;
 11800     }
 11801   Lisp_Object quit = make_fixnum (quit_char);
 11802 
 11803   return list4 (interrupt, flow, meta, quit);
 11804 }
 11805 
 11806 DEFUN ("posn-at-x-y", Fposn_at_x_y, Sposn_at_x_y, 2, 4, 0,
 11807        doc: /* Return position information for pixel coordinates X and Y.
 11808 By default, X and Y are relative to text area of the selected window.
 11809 Note that the text area includes the header-line and the tab-line of
 11810 the window, if any of them are present.
 11811 Optional third arg FRAME-OR-WINDOW non-nil specifies frame or window.
 11812 If optional fourth arg WHOLE is non-nil, X is relative to the left
 11813 edge of the window.
 11814 
 11815 The return value is similar to a mouse click position:
 11816    (WINDOW AREA-OR-POS (X . Y) TIMESTAMP OBJECT POS (COL . ROW)
 11817     IMAGE (DX . DY) (WIDTH . HEIGHT))
 11818 The `posn-' functions access elements of such lists.  */)
 11819   (Lisp_Object x, Lisp_Object y, Lisp_Object frame_or_window, Lisp_Object whole)
 11820 {
 11821   CHECK_FIXNUM (x);
 11822   /* We allow X of -1, for the newline in a R2L line that overflowed
 11823      into the left fringe.  */
 11824   if (XFIXNUM (x) != -1)
 11825     CHECK_FIXNAT (x);
 11826   CHECK_FIXNAT (y);
 11827 
 11828   if (NILP (frame_or_window))
 11829     frame_or_window = selected_window;
 11830 
 11831   if (WINDOWP (frame_or_window))
 11832     {
 11833       struct window *w = decode_live_window (frame_or_window);
 11834 
 11835       XSETINT (x, (XFIXNUM (x)
 11836                    + WINDOW_LEFT_EDGE_X (w)
 11837                    + (NILP (whole)
 11838                       ? window_box_left_offset (w, TEXT_AREA)
 11839                       : 0)));
 11840       XSETINT (y, WINDOW_TO_FRAME_PIXEL_Y (w, XFIXNUM (y)));
 11841       frame_or_window = w->frame;
 11842     }
 11843 
 11844   CHECK_LIVE_FRAME (frame_or_window);
 11845 
 11846   return make_lispy_position (XFRAME (frame_or_window), x, y, 0);
 11847 }
 11848 
 11849 DEFUN ("posn-at-point", Fposn_at_point, Sposn_at_point, 0, 2, 0,
 11850        doc: /* Return position information for buffer position POS in WINDOW.
 11851 POS defaults to point in WINDOW; WINDOW defaults to the selected window.
 11852 
 11853 If POS is in invisible text or is hidden by `display' properties,
 11854 this function may report on buffer positions before or after POS.
 11855 
 11856 Return nil if POS is not visible in WINDOW.  Otherwise,
 11857 the return value is similar to that returned by `event-start' for
 11858 a mouse click at the upper left corner of the glyph corresponding
 11859 to POS:
 11860    (WINDOW AREA-OR-POS (X . Y) TIMESTAMP OBJECT POS (COL . ROW)
 11861     IMAGE (DX . DY) (WIDTH . HEIGHT))
 11862 The `posn-' functions access elements of such lists.  */)
 11863   (Lisp_Object pos, Lisp_Object window)
 11864 {
 11865   Lisp_Object tem;
 11866 
 11867   if (NILP (window))
 11868     window = selected_window;
 11869 
 11870   tem = Fpos_visible_in_window_p (pos, window, Qt);
 11871   if (!NILP (tem))
 11872     {
 11873       Lisp_Object x = XCAR (tem);
 11874       Lisp_Object y = XCAR (XCDR (tem));
 11875       Lisp_Object aux_info = XCDR (XCDR (tem));
 11876       int y_coord = XFIXNUM (y);
 11877 
 11878       /* Point invisible due to hscrolling?  X can be -1 when a
 11879          newline in a R2L line overflows into the left fringe.  */
 11880       if (XFIXNUM (x) < -1)
 11881         return Qnil;
 11882       if (!NILP (aux_info) && y_coord < 0)
 11883         {
 11884           int rtop = XFIXNUM (XCAR (aux_info));
 11885 
 11886           y = make_fixnum (y_coord + rtop);
 11887         }
 11888       tem = Fposn_at_x_y (x, y, window, Qnil);
 11889     }
 11890 
 11891   return tem;
 11892 }
 11893 
 11894 /* Set up a new kboard object with reasonable initial values.
 11895    TYPE is a window system for which this keyboard is used.  */
 11896 
 11897 static void
 11898 init_kboard (KBOARD *kb, Lisp_Object type)
 11899 {
 11900   kset_overriding_terminal_local_map (kb, Qnil);
 11901   kset_last_command (kb, Qnil);
 11902   kset_real_last_command (kb, Qnil);
 11903   kset_keyboard_translate_table (kb, Qnil);
 11904   kset_last_repeatable_command (kb, Qnil);
 11905   kset_prefix_arg (kb, Qnil);
 11906   kset_last_prefix_arg (kb, Qnil);
 11907   kset_kbd_queue (kb, Qnil);
 11908   kb->kbd_queue_has_data = false;
 11909   kb->immediate_echo = false;
 11910   kset_echo_string (kb, Qnil);
 11911   kset_echo_prompt (kb, Qnil);
 11912   kb->kbd_macro_buffer = 0;
 11913   kb->kbd_macro_bufsize = 0;
 11914   kset_defining_kbd_macro (kb, Qnil);
 11915   kset_last_kbd_macro (kb, Qnil);
 11916   kb->reference_count = 0;
 11917   kset_system_key_alist (kb, Qnil);
 11918   kset_system_key_syms (kb, Qnil);
 11919   kset_window_system (kb, type);
 11920   kset_input_decode_map (kb, Fmake_sparse_keymap (Qnil));
 11921   kset_local_function_key_map (kb, Fmake_sparse_keymap (Qnil));
 11922   Fset_keymap_parent (KVAR (kb, Vlocal_function_key_map), Vfunction_key_map);
 11923   kset_default_minibuffer_frame (kb, Qnil);
 11924 }
 11925 
 11926 /* Allocate and basically initialize keyboard
 11927    object to use with window system TYPE.  */
 11928 
 11929 KBOARD *
 11930 allocate_kboard (Lisp_Object type)
 11931 {
 11932   KBOARD *kb = xmalloc (sizeof *kb);
 11933 
 11934   init_kboard (kb, type);
 11935   kb->next_kboard = all_kboards;
 11936   all_kboards = kb;
 11937   return kb;
 11938 }
 11939 
 11940 /*
 11941  * Destroy the contents of a kboard object, but not the object itself.
 11942  * We use this just before deleting it, or if we're going to initialize
 11943  * it a second time.
 11944  */
 11945 static void
 11946 wipe_kboard (KBOARD *kb)
 11947 {
 11948   xfree (kb->kbd_macro_buffer);
 11949 }
 11950 
 11951 /* Free KB and memory referenced from it.  */
 11952 
 11953 void
 11954 delete_kboard (KBOARD *kb)
 11955 {
 11956   KBOARD **kbp;
 11957 
 11958   for (kbp = &all_kboards; *kbp != kb; kbp = &(*kbp)->next_kboard)
 11959     if (*kbp == NULL)
 11960       emacs_abort ();
 11961   *kbp = kb->next_kboard;
 11962 
 11963   /* Prevent a dangling reference to KB.  */
 11964   if (kb == current_kboard
 11965       && FRAMEP (selected_frame)
 11966       && FRAME_LIVE_P (XFRAME (selected_frame)))
 11967     {
 11968       current_kboard = FRAME_KBOARD (XFRAME (selected_frame));
 11969       single_kboard = false;
 11970       if (current_kboard == kb)
 11971         emacs_abort ();
 11972     }
 11973 
 11974   wipe_kboard (kb);
 11975   xfree (kb);
 11976 }
 11977 
 11978 void
 11979 init_keyboard (void)
 11980 {
 11981   /* This is correct before outermost invocation of the editor loop.  */
 11982   command_loop_level = -1;
 11983   quit_char = Ctl ('g');
 11984   Vunread_command_events = Qnil;
 11985   timer_idleness_start_time = invalid_timespec ();
 11986   total_keys = 0;
 11987   recent_keys_index = 0;
 11988   kbd_fetch_ptr = kbd_buffer;
 11989   kbd_store_ptr = kbd_buffer;
 11990   track_mouse = Qnil;
 11991   input_pending = false;
 11992   interrupt_input_blocked = 0;
 11993   pending_signals = false;
 11994 
 11995   virtual_core_pointer_name = build_string ("Virtual core pointer");
 11996   virtual_core_keyboard_name = build_string ("Virtual core keyboard");
 11997   Vlast_event_device = Qnil;
 11998 
 11999   /* This means that command_loop_1 won't try to select anything the first
 12000      time through.  */
 12001   internal_last_event_frame = Qnil;
 12002   Vlast_event_frame = internal_last_event_frame;
 12003 
 12004   current_kboard = initial_kboard;
 12005   /* Re-initialize the keyboard again.  */
 12006   wipe_kboard (current_kboard);
 12007   /* A value of nil for Vwindow_system normally means a tty, but we also use
 12008      it for the initial terminal since there is no window system there.  */
 12009   init_kboard (current_kboard, Qnil);
 12010 
 12011   if (!noninteractive)
 12012     {
 12013       /* Before multi-tty support, these handlers used to be installed
 12014          only if the current session was a tty session.  Now an Emacs
 12015          session may have multiple display types, so we always handle
 12016          SIGINT.  There is special code in handle_interrupt_signal to exit
 12017          Emacs on SIGINT when there are no termcap frames on the
 12018          controlling terminal.  */
 12019       struct sigaction action;
 12020       emacs_sigaction_init (&action, deliver_interrupt_signal);
 12021       sigaction (SIGINT, &action, 0);
 12022 #ifndef DOS_NT
 12023       /* For systems with SysV TERMIO, C-g is set up for both SIGINT and
 12024          SIGQUIT and we can't tell which one it will give us.  */
 12025       sigaction (SIGQUIT, &action, 0);
 12026 #endif /* not DOS_NT */
 12027     }
 12028 #if defined (USABLE_SIGIO) || defined (USABLE_SIGPOLL)
 12029   if (!noninteractive)
 12030     {
 12031       struct sigaction action;
 12032       emacs_sigaction_init (&action, deliver_input_available_signal);
 12033 #ifdef USABLE_SIGIO
 12034       sigaction (SIGIO, &action, 0);
 12035 #else
 12036       sigaction (SIGPOLL, &action, 0);
 12037 #endif
 12038     }
 12039 #endif
 12040 
 12041 /* Use interrupt input by default, if it works and noninterrupt input
 12042    has deficiencies.  */
 12043 
 12044 #ifdef INTERRUPT_INPUT
 12045   interrupt_input = 1;
 12046 #else
 12047   interrupt_input = 0;
 12048 #endif
 12049 
 12050   pthread_sigmask (SIG_SETMASK, &empty_mask, 0);
 12051   dribble = 0;
 12052 
 12053   if (keyboard_init_hook)
 12054     (*keyboard_init_hook) ();
 12055 
 12056 #ifdef POLL_FOR_INPUT
 12057   poll_timer = NULL;
 12058   poll_suppress_count = 1;
 12059   start_polling ();
 12060 #endif
 12061 }
 12062 
 12063 /* This type's only use is in syms_of_keyboard, to put properties on the
 12064    event header symbols.  */
 12065 struct event_head
 12066 {
 12067   short var;
 12068   short kind;
 12069 };
 12070 
 12071 static const struct event_head head_table[] = {
 12072   {SYMBOL_INDEX (Qmouse_movement),      SYMBOL_INDEX (Qmouse_movement)},
 12073   {SYMBOL_INDEX (Qscroll_bar_movement), SYMBOL_INDEX (Qmouse_movement)},
 12074 
 12075   /* Some of the event heads.  */
 12076   {SYMBOL_INDEX (Qswitch_frame),        SYMBOL_INDEX (Qswitch_frame)},
 12077 
 12078   {SYMBOL_INDEX (Qfocus_in),            SYMBOL_INDEX (Qfocus_in)},
 12079   {SYMBOL_INDEX (Qfocus_out),           SYMBOL_INDEX (Qfocus_out)},
 12080   {SYMBOL_INDEX (Qmove_frame),          SYMBOL_INDEX (Qmove_frame)},
 12081   {SYMBOL_INDEX (Qdelete_frame),        SYMBOL_INDEX (Qdelete_frame)},
 12082   {SYMBOL_INDEX (Qiconify_frame),       SYMBOL_INDEX (Qiconify_frame)},
 12083   {SYMBOL_INDEX (Qmake_frame_visible),  SYMBOL_INDEX (Qmake_frame_visible)},
 12084   /* `select-window' should be handled just like `switch-frame'
 12085      in read_key_sequence.  */
 12086   {SYMBOL_INDEX (Qselect_window),       SYMBOL_INDEX (Qswitch_frame)}
 12087 };
 12088 
 12089 static Lisp_Object
 12090 init_while_no_input_ignore_events (void)
 12091 {
 12092   Lisp_Object events = listn (9, Qselect_window, Qhelp_echo, Qmove_frame,
 12093                               Qiconify_frame, Qmake_frame_visible,
 12094                               Qfocus_in, Qfocus_out, Qconfig_changed_event,
 12095                               Qselection_request);
 12096 
 12097 #ifdef HAVE_DBUS
 12098   events = Fcons (Qdbus_event, events);
 12099 #endif
 12100 #ifdef USE_FILE_NOTIFY
 12101   events = Fcons (Qfile_notify, events);
 12102 #endif
 12103 #ifdef THREADS_ENABLED
 12104   events = Fcons (Qthread_event, events);
 12105 #endif
 12106 
 12107   return events;
 12108 }
 12109 
 12110 static bool
 12111 is_ignored_event (union buffered_input_event *event)
 12112 {
 12113   Lisp_Object ignore_event;
 12114 
 12115   switch (event->kind)
 12116     {
 12117     case FOCUS_IN_EVENT: ignore_event = Qfocus_in; break;
 12118     case FOCUS_OUT_EVENT: ignore_event = Qfocus_out; break;
 12119     case HELP_EVENT: ignore_event = Qhelp_echo; break;
 12120     case ICONIFY_EVENT: ignore_event = Qiconify_frame; break;
 12121     case DEICONIFY_EVENT: ignore_event = Qmake_frame_visible; break;
 12122     case SELECTION_REQUEST_EVENT: ignore_event = Qselection_request; break;
 12123 #ifdef USE_FILE_NOTIFY
 12124     case FILE_NOTIFY_EVENT: ignore_event = Qfile_notify; break;
 12125 #endif
 12126 #ifdef HAVE_DBUS
 12127     case DBUS_EVENT: ignore_event = Qdbus_event; break;
 12128 #endif
 12129     default: ignore_event = Qnil; break;
 12130     }
 12131 
 12132   return !NILP (Fmemq (ignore_event, Vwhile_no_input_ignore_events));
 12133 }
 12134 
 12135 static void syms_of_keyboard_for_pdumper (void);
 12136 
 12137 void
 12138 syms_of_keyboard (void)
 12139 {
 12140   pending_funcalls = Qnil;
 12141   staticpro (&pending_funcalls);
 12142 
 12143   Vlispy_mouse_stem = build_pure_c_string ("mouse");
 12144   staticpro (&Vlispy_mouse_stem);
 12145 
 12146   regular_top_level_message = build_pure_c_string ("Back to top level");
 12147   staticpro (&regular_top_level_message);
 12148 #ifdef HAVE_STACK_OVERFLOW_HANDLING
 12149   recover_top_level_message
 12150     = build_pure_c_string ("Re-entering top level after C stack overflow");
 12151   staticpro (&recover_top_level_message);
 12152 #endif
 12153   DEFVAR_LISP ("internal--top-level-message", Vinternal__top_level_message,
 12154                doc: /* Message displayed by `normal-top-level'.  */);
 12155   Vinternal__top_level_message = regular_top_level_message;
 12156 
 12157   /* Tool-bars.  */
 12158   DEFSYM (QCimage, ":image");
 12159   DEFSYM (Qhelp_echo, "help-echo");
 12160   DEFSYM (Qhelp_echo_inhibit_substitution, "help-echo-inhibit-substitution");
 12161   DEFSYM (QCrtl, ":rtl");
 12162 
 12163   staticpro (&item_properties);
 12164   item_properties = Qnil;
 12165 
 12166   staticpro (&tab_bar_item_properties);
 12167   tab_bar_item_properties = Qnil;
 12168   staticpro (&tab_bar_items_vector);
 12169   tab_bar_items_vector = Qnil;
 12170 
 12171   staticpro (&tool_bar_item_properties);
 12172   tool_bar_item_properties = Qnil;
 12173   staticpro (&tool_bar_items_vector);
 12174   tool_bar_items_vector = Qnil;
 12175 
 12176   DEFSYM (Qtimer_event_handler, "timer-event-handler");
 12177 
 12178   /* Non-nil disable property on a command means do not execute it;
 12179      call disabled-command-function's value instead.  */
 12180   DEFSYM (Qdisabled, "disabled");
 12181 
 12182   DEFSYM (Qundefined, "undefined");
 12183 
 12184   /* Hooks to run before and after each command.  */
 12185   DEFSYM (Qpre_command_hook, "pre-command-hook");
 12186   DEFSYM (Qpost_command_hook, "post-command-hook");
 12187   DEFSYM (Qlong_line_optimizations_in_command_hooks,
 12188           "long-line-optimizations-in-command-hooks");
 12189 
 12190   /* Hook run after the region is selected.  */
 12191   DEFSYM (Qpost_select_region_hook, "post-select-region-hook");
 12192 
 12193   DEFSYM (Qundo_auto__add_boundary, "undo-auto--add-boundary");
 12194   DEFSYM (Qundo_auto__undoably_changed_buffers,
 12195           "undo-auto--undoably-changed-buffers");
 12196 
 12197   DEFSYM (Qdelayed_warnings_hook, "delayed-warnings-hook");
 12198   DEFSYM (Qfunction_key, "function-key");
 12199 
 12200   /* The values of Qevent_kind properties.  */
 12201   DEFSYM (Qmouse_click, "mouse-click");
 12202 
 12203   DEFSYM (Qdrag_n_drop, "drag-n-drop");
 12204   DEFSYM (Qsave_session, "save-session");
 12205   DEFSYM (Qconfig_changed_event, "config-changed-event");
 12206 
 12207   /* Menu and tool bar item parts.  */
 12208   DEFSYM (Qmenu_enable, "menu-enable");
 12209 
 12210 #ifdef HAVE_NTGUI
 12211   DEFSYM (Qlanguage_change, "language-change");
 12212   DEFSYM (Qend_session, "end-session");
 12213 #endif
 12214 
 12215 #ifdef HAVE_DBUS
 12216   DEFSYM (Qdbus_event, "dbus-event");
 12217 #endif
 12218 
 12219 #ifdef THREADS_ENABLED
 12220   DEFSYM (Qthread_event, "thread-event");
 12221 #endif
 12222 
 12223 #ifdef HAVE_XWIDGETS
 12224   DEFSYM (Qxwidget_event, "xwidget-event");
 12225   DEFSYM (Qxwidget_display_event, "xwidget-display-event");
 12226 #endif
 12227 
 12228 #ifdef USE_FILE_NOTIFY
 12229   DEFSYM (Qfile_notify, "file-notify");
 12230 #endif /* USE_FILE_NOTIFY */
 12231 
 12232   DEFSYM (Qtouch_end, "touch-end");
 12233 
 12234   /* Menu and tool bar item parts.  */
 12235   DEFSYM (QCenable, ":enable");
 12236   DEFSYM (QCvisible, ":visible");
 12237   DEFSYM (QChelp, ":help");
 12238   DEFSYM (QCfilter, ":filter");
 12239   DEFSYM (QCbutton, ":button");
 12240   DEFSYM (QCkeys, ":keys");
 12241   DEFSYM (QCkey_sequence, ":key-sequence");
 12242 
 12243   /* Non-nil disable property on a command means
 12244      do not execute it; call disabled-command-function's value instead.  */
 12245   DEFSYM (QCtoggle, ":toggle");
 12246   DEFSYM (QCradio, ":radio");
 12247   DEFSYM (QClabel, ":label");
 12248   DEFSYM (QCvert_only, ":vert-only");
 12249 
 12250   /* Symbols to use for parts of windows.  */
 12251   DEFSYM (Qvertical_line, "vertical-line");
 12252   DEFSYM (Qright_divider, "right-divider");
 12253   DEFSYM (Qbottom_divider, "bottom-divider");
 12254 
 12255   DEFSYM (Qmouse_fixup_help_message, "mouse-fixup-help-message");
 12256 
 12257   DEFSYM (Qabove_handle, "above-handle");
 12258   DEFSYM (Qhandle, "handle");
 12259   DEFSYM (Qbelow_handle, "below-handle");
