 12260   DEFSYM (Qup, "up");
 12261   DEFSYM (Qdown, "down");
 12262   DEFSYM (Qtop, "top");
 12263   DEFSYM (Qbottom, "bottom");
 12264   DEFSYM (Qend_scroll, "end-scroll");
 12265   DEFSYM (Qratio, "ratio");
 12266   DEFSYM (Qbefore_handle, "before-handle");
 12267   DEFSYM (Qhorizontal_handle, "horizontal-handle");
 12268   DEFSYM (Qafter_handle, "after-handle");
 12269   DEFSYM (Qleft, "left");
 12270   DEFSYM (Qright, "right");
 12271   DEFSYM (Qleftmost, "leftmost");
 12272   DEFSYM (Qrightmost, "rightmost");
 12273 
 12274   /* Properties of event headers.  */
 12275   DEFSYM (Qevent_kind, "event-kind");
 12276   DEFSYM (Qevent_symbol_elements, "event-symbol-elements");
 12277 
 12278   /* An event header symbol HEAD may have a property named
 12279      Qevent_symbol_element_mask, which is of the form (BASE MODIFIERS);
 12280      BASE is the base, unmodified version of HEAD, and MODIFIERS is the
 12281      mask of modifiers applied to it.  If present, this is used to help
 12282      speed up parse_modifiers.  */
 12283   DEFSYM (Qevent_symbol_element_mask, "event-symbol-element-mask");
 12284 
 12285   /* An unmodified event header BASE may have a property named
 12286      Qmodifier_cache, which is an alist mapping modifier masks onto
 12287      modified versions of BASE.  If present, this helps speed up
 12288      apply_modifiers.  */
 12289   DEFSYM (Qmodifier_cache, "modifier-cache");
 12290 
 12291   DEFSYM (Qactivate_menubar_hook, "activate-menubar-hook");
 12292 
 12293   DEFSYM (Qpolling_period, "polling-period");
 12294 
 12295   DEFSYM (Qgui_set_selection, "gui-set-selection");
 12296   DEFSYM (Qxterm__set_selection, "xterm--set-selection");
 12297   DEFSYM (Qtty_select_active_regions, "tty-select-active-regions");
 12298 
 12299   /* The primary selection.  */
 12300   DEFSYM (QPRIMARY, "PRIMARY");
 12301 
 12302   DEFSYM (Qhandle_switch_frame, "handle-switch-frame");
 12303   DEFSYM (Qhandle_select_window, "handle-select-window");
 12304 
 12305   DEFSYM (Qinput_method_exit_on_first_char, "input-method-exit-on-first-char");
 12306   DEFSYM (Qinput_method_use_echo_area, "input-method-use-echo-area");
 12307 
 12308   DEFSYM (Qhelp_form_show, "help-form-show");
 12309 
 12310   DEFSYM (Qhelp_key_binding, "help-key-binding");
 12311 
 12312   DEFSYM (Qecho_keystrokes, "echo-keystrokes");
 12313 
 12314   Fset (Qinput_method_exit_on_first_char, Qnil);
 12315   Fset (Qinput_method_use_echo_area, Qnil);
 12316 
 12317   /* Symbols for dragging internal borders.  */
 12318   DEFSYM (Qdrag_internal_border, "drag-internal-border");
 12319   DEFSYM (Qleft_edge, "left-edge");
 12320   DEFSYM (Qtop_left_corner, "top-left-corner");
 12321   DEFSYM (Qtop_edge, "top-edge");
 12322   DEFSYM (Qtop_right_corner, "top-right-corner");
 12323   DEFSYM (Qright_edge, "right-edge");
 12324   DEFSYM (Qbottom_right_corner, "bottom-right-corner");
 12325   DEFSYM (Qbottom_edge, "bottom-edge");
 12326   DEFSYM (Qbottom_left_corner, "bottom-left-corner");
 12327 
 12328   /* Symbols to head events.  */
 12329   DEFSYM (Qmouse_movement, "mouse-movement");
 12330   DEFSYM (Qscroll_bar_movement, "scroll-bar-movement");
 12331   DEFSYM (Qswitch_frame, "switch-frame");
 12332   DEFSYM (Qfocus_in, "focus-in");
 12333   DEFSYM (Qfocus_out, "focus-out");
 12334   DEFSYM (Qmove_frame, "move-frame");
 12335   DEFSYM (Qdelete_frame, "delete-frame");
 12336   DEFSYM (Qiconify_frame, "iconify-frame");
 12337   DEFSYM (Qmake_frame_visible, "make-frame-visible");
 12338   DEFSYM (Qselect_window, "select-window");
 12339   DEFSYM (Qselection_request, "selection-request");
 12340   DEFSYM (Qwindow_edges, "window-edges");
 12341   {
 12342     int i;
 12343 
 12344     for (i = 0; i < ARRAYELTS (head_table); i++)
 12345       {
 12346         const struct event_head *p = &head_table[i];
 12347         Lisp_Object var = builtin_lisp_symbol (p->var);
 12348         Lisp_Object kind = builtin_lisp_symbol (p->kind);
 12349         Fput (var, Qevent_kind, kind);
 12350         Fput (var, Qevent_symbol_elements, list1 (var));
 12351       }
 12352   }
 12353   DEFSYM (Qno_record, "no-record");
 12354   DEFSYM (Qencoded, "encoded");
 12355 
 12356   DEFSYM (Qpreedit_text, "preedit-text");
 12357 
 12358   button_down_location = make_nil_vector (5);
 12359   staticpro (&button_down_location);
 12360   staticpro (&frame_relative_event_pos);
 12361   mouse_syms = make_nil_vector (5);
 12362   staticpro (&mouse_syms);
 12363   wheel_syms = make_nil_vector (ARRAYELTS (lispy_wheel_names));
 12364   staticpro (&wheel_syms);
 12365 
 12366   {
 12367     int i;
 12368     int len = ARRAYELTS (modifier_names);
 12369 
 12370     modifier_symbols = make_nil_vector (len);
 12371     for (i = 0; i < len; i++)
 12372       if (modifier_names[i])
 12373         ASET (modifier_symbols, i, intern_c_string (modifier_names[i]));
 12374     staticpro (&modifier_symbols);
 12375   }
 12376 
 12377   recent_keys = make_nil_vector (lossage_limit);
 12378   staticpro (&recent_keys);
 12379 
 12380   this_command_keys = make_nil_vector (40);
 12381   staticpro (&this_command_keys);
 12382 
 12383   raw_keybuf = make_nil_vector (30);
 12384   staticpro (&raw_keybuf);
 12385 
 12386   DEFSYM (Qcommand_execute, "command-execute");
 12387   DEFSYM (Qinternal_echo_keystrokes_prefix, "internal-echo-keystrokes-prefix");
 12388 
 12389   accent_key_syms = Qnil;
 12390   staticpro (&accent_key_syms);
 12391 
 12392   func_key_syms = Qnil;
 12393   staticpro (&func_key_syms);
 12394 
 12395   drag_n_drop_syms = Qnil;
 12396   staticpro (&drag_n_drop_syms);
 12397 
 12398   pinch_syms = Qnil;
 12399   staticpro (&pinch_syms);
 12400 
 12401   unread_switch_frame = Qnil;
 12402   staticpro (&unread_switch_frame);
 12403 
 12404   internal_last_event_frame = Qnil;
 12405   staticpro (&internal_last_event_frame);
 12406 
 12407   read_key_sequence_cmd = Qnil;
 12408   staticpro (&read_key_sequence_cmd);
 12409   read_key_sequence_remapped = Qnil;
 12410   staticpro (&read_key_sequence_remapped);
 12411 
 12412   menu_bar_one_keymap_changed_items = Qnil;
 12413   staticpro (&menu_bar_one_keymap_changed_items);
 12414 
 12415   menu_bar_items_vector = Qnil;
 12416   staticpro (&menu_bar_items_vector);
 12417 
 12418   help_form_saved_window_configs = Qnil;
 12419   staticpro (&help_form_saved_window_configs);
 12420 
 12421 #ifdef POLL_FOR_INPUT
 12422   poll_timer_time = Qnil;
 12423   staticpro (&poll_timer_time);
 12424 #endif
 12425 
 12426   virtual_core_pointer_name = Qnil;
 12427   staticpro (&virtual_core_pointer_name);
 12428 
 12429   virtual_core_keyboard_name = Qnil;
 12430   staticpro (&virtual_core_keyboard_name);
 12431 
 12432   defsubr (&Scurrent_idle_time);
 12433   defsubr (&Sevent_symbol_parse_modifiers);
 12434   defsubr (&Sevent_convert_list);
 12435   defsubr (&Sinternal_handle_focus_in);
 12436   defsubr (&Sread_key_sequence);
 12437   defsubr (&Sread_key_sequence_vector);
 12438   defsubr (&Srecursive_edit);
 12439   defsubr (&Sinternal_track_mouse);
 12440   defsubr (&Sinput_pending_p);
 12441   defsubr (&Slossage_size);
 12442   defsubr (&Srecent_keys);
 12443   defsubr (&Sthis_command_keys);
 12444   defsubr (&Sthis_command_keys_vector);
 12445   defsubr (&Sthis_single_command_keys);
 12446   defsubr (&Sthis_single_command_raw_keys);
 12447   defsubr (&Sset__this_command_keys);
 12448   defsubr (&Sclear_this_command_keys);
 12449   defsubr (&Ssuspend_emacs);
 12450   defsubr (&Sabort_recursive_edit);
 12451   defsubr (&Sexit_recursive_edit);
 12452   defsubr (&Srecursion_depth);
 12453   defsubr (&Scommand_error_default_function);
 12454   defsubr (&Stop_level);
 12455   defsubr (&Sdiscard_input);
 12456   defsubr (&Sopen_dribble_file);
 12457   defsubr (&Sset_input_interrupt_mode);
 12458   defsubr (&Sset_output_flow_control);
 12459   defsubr (&Sset_input_meta_mode);
 12460   defsubr (&Sset_quit_char);
 12461   defsubr (&Sset_input_mode);
 12462   defsubr (&Scurrent_input_mode);
 12463   defsubr (&Sposn_at_point);
 12464   defsubr (&Sposn_at_x_y);
 12465 
 12466   DEFVAR_LISP ("last-command-event", last_command_event,
 12467                      doc: /* Last input event of a key sequence that called a command.
 12468 See Info node `(elisp)Command Loop Info'.*/);
 12469 
 12470   DEFVAR_LISP ("last-nonmenu-event", last_nonmenu_event,
 12471                doc: /* Last input event in a command, except for mouse menu events.
 12472 Mouse menus give back keys that don't look like mouse events;
 12473 this variable holds the actual mouse event that led to the menu,
 12474 so that you can determine whether the command was run by mouse or not.  */);
 12475 
 12476   DEFVAR_LISP ("last-input-event", last_input_event,
 12477                doc: /* Last input event.  */);
 12478 
 12479   DEFVAR_LISP ("unread-command-events", Vunread_command_events,
 12480                doc: /* List of events to be read as the command input.
 12481 These events are processed first, before actual keyboard input.
 12482 Events read from this list are not normally added to `this-command-keys',
 12483 as they will already have been added once as they were read for the first time.
 12484 An element of the form (t . EVENT) forces EVENT to be added to that list.
 12485 An element of the form (no-record . EVENT) means process EVENT, but do not
 12486 record it in the keyboard macros, recent-keys, and the dribble file.  */);
 12487   Vunread_command_events = Qnil;
 12488 
 12489   DEFVAR_LISP ("unread-post-input-method-events", Vunread_post_input_method_events,
 12490                doc: /* List of events to be processed as input by input methods.
 12491 These events are processed before `unread-command-events'
 12492 and actual keyboard input, but are not given to `input-method-function'.  */);
 12493   Vunread_post_input_method_events = Qnil;
 12494 
 12495   DEFVAR_LISP ("unread-input-method-events", Vunread_input_method_events,
 12496                doc: /* List of events to be processed as input by input methods.
 12497 These events are processed after `unread-command-events', but
 12498 before actual keyboard input.
 12499 If there's an active input method, the events are given to
 12500 `input-method-function'.  */);
 12501   Vunread_input_method_events = Qnil;
 12502 
 12503   DEFVAR_LISP ("meta-prefix-char", meta_prefix_char,
 12504                doc: /* Meta-prefix character code.
 12505 Meta-foo as command input turns into this character followed by foo.  */);
 12506   XSETINT (meta_prefix_char, 033);
 12507 
 12508   DEFVAR_KBOARD ("last-command", Vlast_command,
 12509                  doc: /* The last command executed.
 12510 Normally a symbol with a function definition, but can be whatever was found
 12511 in the keymap, or whatever the variable `this-command' was set to by that
 12512 command.
 12513 
 12514 The value `mode-exit' is special; it means that the previous command
 12515 read an event that told it to exit, and it did so and unread that event.
 12516 In other words, the present command is the event that made the previous
 12517 command exit.
 12518 
 12519 The value `kill-region' is special; it means that the previous command
 12520 was a kill command.
 12521 
 12522 `last-command' has a separate binding for each terminal device.
 12523 See Info node `(elisp)Multiple Terminals'.  */);
 12524 
 12525   DEFVAR_KBOARD ("real-last-command", Vreal_last_command,
 12526                  doc: /* Same as `last-command', but never altered by Lisp code.
 12527 Taken from the previous value of `real-this-command'.  */);
 12528 
 12529   DEFVAR_KBOARD ("last-repeatable-command", Vlast_repeatable_command,
 12530                  doc: /* Last command that may be repeated.
 12531 The last command executed that was not bound to an input event.
 12532 This is the command `repeat' will try to repeat.
 12533 Taken from a previous value of `real-this-command'.  */);
 12534 
 12535   DEFVAR_LISP ("this-command", Vthis_command,
 12536                doc: /* The command now being executed.
 12537 The command can set this variable; whatever is put here
 12538 will be in `last-command' during the following command.  */);
 12539   Vthis_command = Qnil;
 12540 
 12541   DEFVAR_LISP ("real-this-command", Vreal_this_command,
 12542                doc: /* This is like `this-command', except that commands should never modify it.  */);
 12543   Vreal_this_command = Qnil;
 12544 
 12545   DEFSYM (Qcurrent_minibuffer_command, "current-minibuffer-command");
 12546   DEFVAR_LISP ("current-minibuffer-command", Vcurrent_minibuffer_command,
 12547                doc: /* This is like `this-command', but bound recursively.
 12548 Code running from (for instance) a minibuffer hook can check this variable
 12549 to see what command invoked the current minibuffer.  */);
 12550   Vcurrent_minibuffer_command = Qnil;
 12551 
 12552   DEFVAR_LISP ("this-command-keys-shift-translated",
 12553                Vthis_command_keys_shift_translated,
 12554                doc: /* Non-nil if the key sequence activating this command was shift-translated.
 12555 Shift-translation occurs when there is no binding for the key sequence
 12556 as entered, but a binding was found by changing an upper-case letter
 12557 to lower-case, or a shifted function key to an unshifted one.  */);
 12558   Vthis_command_keys_shift_translated = Qnil;
 12559 
 12560   DEFVAR_LISP ("this-original-command", Vthis_original_command,
 12561                doc: /* The command bound to the current key sequence before remapping.
 12562 It equals `this-command' if the original command was not remapped through
 12563 any of the active keymaps.  Otherwise, the value of `this-command' is the
 12564 result of looking up the original command in the active keymaps.  */);
 12565   Vthis_original_command = Qnil;
 12566 
 12567   DEFVAR_INT ("auto-save-interval", auto_save_interval,
 12568               doc: /* Number of input events between auto-saves.
 12569 Zero means disable autosaving due to number of characters typed.  */);
 12570   auto_save_interval = 300;
 12571 
 12572   DEFVAR_BOOL ("auto-save-no-message", auto_save_no_message,
 12573                doc: /* Non-nil means do not print any message when auto-saving. */);
 12574   auto_save_no_message = false;
 12575 
 12576   DEFVAR_LISP ("auto-save-timeout", Vauto_save_timeout,
 12577                doc: /* Number of seconds idle time before auto-save.
 12578 Zero or nil means disable auto-saving due to idleness.
 12579 After auto-saving due to this many seconds of idle time,
 12580 Emacs also does a garbage collection if that seems to be warranted.  */);
 12581   XSETFASTINT (Vauto_save_timeout, 30);
 12582 
 12583   DEFVAR_LISP ("echo-keystrokes", Vecho_keystrokes,
 12584                doc: /* Nonzero means echo unfinished commands after this many seconds of pause.
 12585 The value may be integer or floating point.
 12586 If the value is zero, don't echo at all.  */);
 12587   Vecho_keystrokes = make_fixnum (1);
 12588 
 12589   DEFVAR_LISP ("polling-period", Vpolling_period,
 12590               doc: /* Interval between polling for input during Lisp execution.
 12591 The reason for polling is to make C-g work to stop a running program.
 12592 Polling is needed only when using X windows and SIGIO does not work.
 12593 Polling is automatically disabled in all other cases.  */);
 12594   Vpolling_period = make_float (2.0);
 12595 
 12596   DEFVAR_LISP ("double-click-time", Vdouble_click_time,
 12597                doc: /* Maximum time between mouse clicks to make a double-click.
 12598 Measured in milliseconds.  The value nil means disable double-click
 12599 recognition; t means double-clicks have no time limit and are detected
 12600 by position only.
 12601 
 12602 In Lisp, you might want to use `mouse-double-click-time' instead of
 12603 reading the value of this variable directly.  */);
 12604   Vdouble_click_time = make_fixnum (500);
 12605 
 12606   DEFVAR_INT ("double-click-fuzz", double_click_fuzz,
 12607               doc: /* Maximum mouse movement between clicks to make a double-click.
 12608 On window-system frames, value is the number of pixels the mouse may have
 12609 moved horizontally or vertically between two clicks to make a double-click.
 12610 On non window-system frames, value is interpreted in units of 1/8 characters
 12611 instead of pixels.
 12612 
 12613 This variable is also the threshold for motion of the mouse
 12614 to count as a drag.  */);
 12615   double_click_fuzz = 3;
 12616 
 12617   DEFVAR_INT ("num-input-keys", num_input_keys,
 12618               doc: /* Number of complete key sequences read as input so far.
 12619 This includes key sequences read from keyboard macros.
 12620 The number is effectively the number of interactive command invocations.  */);
 12621   num_input_keys = 0;
 12622 
 12623   DEFVAR_INT ("num-nonmacro-input-events", num_nonmacro_input_events,
 12624               doc: /* Number of input events read from the keyboard so far.
 12625 This does not include events generated by keyboard macros.  */);
 12626   num_nonmacro_input_events = 0;
 12627 
 12628   DEFVAR_LISP ("last-event-frame", Vlast_event_frame,
 12629                doc: /* The frame in which the most recently read event occurred.
 12630 If the last event came from a keyboard macro, this is set to `macro'.  */);
 12631   Vlast_event_frame = Qnil;
 12632 
 12633   DEFVAR_LISP ("last-event-device", Vlast_event_device,
 12634                doc: /* The name of the input device of the most recently read event.
 12635 When the input extension is being used on X, this is the name of the X
 12636 Input Extension device from which the last event was generated as a
 12637 string.  Otherwise, this is "Virtual core keyboard" for keyboard input
 12638 events, and "Virtual core pointer" for other events.
 12639 
 12640 It is nil if the last event did not come from an input device (i.e. it
 12641 came from `unread-command-events' instead).  */);
 12642   Vlast_event_device = Qnil;
 12643 
 12644   /* This variable is set up in sysdep.c.  */
 12645   DEFVAR_LISP ("tty-erase-char", Vtty_erase_char,
 12646                doc: /* The ERASE character as set by the user with stty.  */);
 12647 
 12648   DEFVAR_LISP ("help-char", Vhelp_char,
 12649                doc: /* Character to recognize as meaning Help.
 12650 When it is read, do `(eval help-form)', and display result if it's a string.
 12651 If the value of `help-form' is nil, this char can be read normally.  */);
 12652   XSETINT (Vhelp_char, Ctl ('H'));
 12653 
 12654   DEFVAR_LISP ("help-event-list", Vhelp_event_list,
 12655                doc: /* List of input events to recognize as meaning Help.
 12656 These work just like the value of `help-char' (see that).  */);
 12657   Vhelp_event_list = Qnil;
 12658 
 12659   DEFVAR_LISP ("help-form", Vhelp_form,
 12660                doc: /* Form to execute when character `help-char' is read.
 12661 If the form returns a string, that string is displayed.
 12662 If `help-form' is nil, the help char is not recognized.  */);
 12663   Vhelp_form = Qnil;
 12664 
 12665   DEFVAR_LISP ("prefix-help-command", Vprefix_help_command,
 12666                doc: /* Command to run when `help-char' character follows a prefix key.
 12667 This command is used only when there is no actual binding
 12668 for that character after that prefix key.  */);
 12669   Vprefix_help_command = Qnil;
 12670 
 12671   DEFVAR_LISP ("top-level", Vtop_level,
 12672                doc: /* Form to evaluate when Emacs starts up.
 12673 Useful to set before you dump a modified Emacs.  */);
 12674   Vtop_level = Qnil;
 12675   XSYMBOL (Qtop_level)->u.s.declared_special = false;
 12676 
 12677   DEFVAR_KBOARD ("keyboard-translate-table", Vkeyboard_translate_table,
 12678                  doc: /* Translate table for local keyboard input, or nil.
 12679 If non-nil, the value should be a char-table.  Each character read
 12680 from the keyboard is looked up in this char-table.  If the value found
 12681 there is non-nil, then it is used instead of the actual input character.
 12682 
 12683 The value can also be a string or vector, but this is considered obsolete.
 12684 If it is a string or vector of length N, character codes N and up are left
 12685 untranslated.  In a vector, an element which is nil means "no translation".
 12686 
 12687 This is applied to the characters supplied to input methods, not their
 12688 output.  See also `translation-table-for-input'.
 12689 
 12690 This variable has a separate binding for each terminal.
 12691 See Info node `(elisp)Multiple Terminals'.  */);
 12692 
 12693   DEFVAR_BOOL ("cannot-suspend", cannot_suspend,
 12694                doc: /* Non-nil means to always spawn a subshell instead of suspending.
 12695 \(Even if the operating system has support for stopping a process.)  */);
 12696   cannot_suspend = false;
 12697 
 12698   DEFVAR_BOOL ("menu-prompting", menu_prompting,
 12699                doc: /* Non-nil means prompt with menus when appropriate.
 12700 This is done when reading from a keymap that has a prompt string,
 12701 for elements that have prompt strings.
 12702 The menu is displayed on the screen
 12703 if X menus were enabled at configuration
 12704 time and the previous event was a mouse click prefix key.
 12705 Otherwise, menu prompting uses the echo area.  */);
 12706   menu_prompting = true;
 12707 
 12708   DEFVAR_LISP ("menu-prompt-more-char", menu_prompt_more_char,
 12709                doc: /* Character to see next line of menu prompt.
 12710 Type this character while in a menu prompt to rotate around the lines of it.  */);
 12711   XSETINT (menu_prompt_more_char, ' ');
 12712 
 12713   DEFVAR_INT ("extra-keyboard-modifiers", extra_keyboard_modifiers,
 12714               doc: /* A mask of additional modifier keys to use with every keyboard character.
 12715 Emacs applies the modifiers of the character stored here to each keyboard
 12716 character it reads.  For example, after evaluating the expression
 12717     (setq extra-keyboard-modifiers ?\\C-x)
 12718 all input characters will have the control modifier applied to them.
 12719 
 12720 Note that the character ?\\C-@, equivalent to the integer zero, does
 12721 not count as a control character; rather, it counts as a character
 12722 with no modifiers; thus, setting `extra-keyboard-modifiers' to zero
 12723 cancels any modification.  */);
 12724   extra_keyboard_modifiers = 0;
 12725 
 12726   DEFSYM (Qdeactivate_mark, "deactivate-mark");
 12727   DEFVAR_LISP ("deactivate-mark", Vdeactivate_mark,
 12728     doc: /* Whether to deactivate the mark after an editing command.
 12729 The command loop sets this to nil before each command,
 12730 and tests the value when the command returns.
 12731 If an editing command sets this non-nil, deactivate the mark after
 12732 the command returns.
 12733 
 12734 Buffer modifications store t in this variable.
 12735 
 12736 By default, deactivating the mark will save the contents of the region
 12737 according to `select-active-regions', unless this is set to the symbol
 12738 `dont-save'.  */);
 12739   Vdeactivate_mark = Qnil;
 12740   Fmake_variable_buffer_local (Qdeactivate_mark);
 12741 
 12742   DEFVAR_LISP ("pre-command-hook", Vpre_command_hook,
 12743                doc: /* Normal hook run before each command is executed.
 12744 
 12745 If an unhandled error happens in running this hook, the function in
 12746 which the error occurred is unconditionally removed, since otherwise
 12747 the error might happen repeatedly and make Emacs nonfunctional.
 12748 
 12749 Note that, when `long-line-optimizations-p' is non-nil in the buffer,
 12750 these functions are called as if they were in a `with-restriction' form,
 12751 with a `long-line-optimizations-in-command-hooks' label and with the
 12752 buffer narrowed to a portion around point whose size is specified by
 12753 `long-line-optimizations-region-size'.
 12754 
 12755 See also `post-command-hook'.  */);
 12756   Vpre_command_hook = Qnil;
 12757 
 12758   DEFVAR_LISP ("post-command-hook", Vpost_command_hook,
 12759                doc: /* Normal hook run after each command is executed.
 12760 
 12761 If an unhandled error happens in running this hook, the function in
 12762 which the error occurred is unconditionally removed, since otherwise
 12763 the error might happen repeatedly and make Emacs nonfunctional.
 12764 
 12765 It is a bad idea to use this hook for expensive processing.  If
 12766 unavoidable, wrap your code in `(while-no-input (redisplay) CODE)' to
 12767 avoid making Emacs unresponsive while the user types.
 12768 
 12769 Note that, when `long-line-optimizations-p' is non-nil in the buffer,
 12770 these functions are called as if they were in a `with-restriction' form,
 12771 with a `long-line-optimizations-in-command-hooks' label and with the
 12772 buffer narrowed to a portion around point whose size is specified by
 12773 `long-line-optimizations-region-size'.
 12774 
 12775 See also `pre-command-hook'.  */);
 12776   Vpost_command_hook = Qnil;
 12777 
 12778 #if 0
 12779   DEFVAR_LISP ("echo-area-clear-hook", ...,
 12780                doc: /* Normal hook run when clearing the echo area.  */);
 12781 #endif
 12782   DEFSYM (Qecho_area_clear_hook, "echo-area-clear-hook");
 12783   DEFSYM (Qtouchscreen_begin, "touchscreen-begin");
 12784   DEFSYM (Qtouchscreen_end, "touchscreen-end");
 12785   DEFSYM (Qtouchscreen_update, "touchscreen-update");
 12786   DEFSYM (Qpinch, "pinch");
 12787   DEFSYM (Qdisplay_monitors_changed_functions,
 12788           "display-monitors-changed-functions");
 12789 
 12790   DEFSYM (Qcoding, "coding");
 12791 
 12792   Fset (Qecho_area_clear_hook, Qnil);
 12793 
 12794 #ifdef USE_LUCID
 12795   DEFVAR_BOOL ("lucid--menu-grab-keyboard",
 12796                lucid__menu_grab_keyboard,
 12797                doc: /* If non-nil, grab keyboard during menu operations.
 12798 This is only relevant when using the Lucid X toolkit.  It can be
 12799 convenient to disable this for debugging purposes.  */);
 12800   lucid__menu_grab_keyboard = true;
 12801 #endif
 12802 
 12803   DEFVAR_LISP ("menu-bar-final-items", Vmenu_bar_final_items,
 12804                doc: /* List of menu bar items to move to the end of the menu bar.
 12805 The elements of the list are event types that may have menu bar
 12806 bindings.  The order of this list controls the order of the items.  */);
 12807   Vmenu_bar_final_items = Qnil;
 12808 
 12809   DEFVAR_LISP ("tab-bar-separator-image-expression", Vtab_bar_separator_image_expression,
 12810     doc: /* Expression evaluating to the image spec for a tab-bar separator.
 12811 This is used internally by graphical displays that do not render
 12812 tab-bar separators natively.  Otherwise it is unused (e.g. on GTK).  */);
 12813   Vtab_bar_separator_image_expression = Qnil;
 12814 
 12815   DEFVAR_LISP ("tool-bar-separator-image-expression", Vtool_bar_separator_image_expression,
 12816     doc: /* Expression evaluating to the image spec for a tool-bar separator.
 12817 This is used internally by graphical displays that do not render
 12818 tool-bar separators natively.  Otherwise it is unused (e.g. on GTK).  */);
 12819   Vtool_bar_separator_image_expression = Qnil;
 12820 
 12821   DEFVAR_KBOARD ("overriding-terminal-local-map",
 12822                  Voverriding_terminal_local_map,
 12823                  doc: /* Per-terminal keymap that takes precedence over all other keymaps.
 12824 This variable is intended to let commands such as `universal-argument'
 12825 set up a different keymap for reading the next command.
 12826 
 12827 `overriding-terminal-local-map' has a separate binding for each
 12828 terminal device.  See Info node `(elisp)Multiple Terminals'.  */);
 12829 
 12830   DEFVAR_LISP ("overriding-local-map", Voverriding_local_map,
 12831                doc: /* Keymap that replaces (overrides) local keymaps.
 12832 If this variable is non-nil, Emacs looks up key bindings in this
 12833 keymap INSTEAD OF `keymap' text properties, `local-map' and `keymap'
 12834 overlay properties, minor mode maps, and the buffer's local map.
 12835 
 12836 Hence, the only active keymaps would be `overriding-terminal-local-map',
 12837 this keymap, and `global-keymap', in order of precedence.  */);
 12838   Voverriding_local_map = Qnil;
 12839 
 12840   DEFVAR_LISP ("overriding-local-map-menu-flag", Voverriding_local_map_menu_flag,
 12841                doc: /* Non-nil means `overriding-local-map' applies to the menu bar.
 12842 Otherwise, the menu bar continues to reflect the buffer's local map
 12843 and the minor mode maps regardless of `overriding-local-map'.  */);
 12844   Voverriding_local_map_menu_flag = Qnil;
 12845 
 12846   DEFVAR_LISP ("special-event-map", Vspecial_event_map,
 12847                doc: /* Keymap defining bindings for special events to execute at low level.  */);
 12848   Vspecial_event_map = list1 (Qkeymap);
 12849 
 12850   DEFVAR_LISP ("track-mouse", track_mouse,
 12851                doc: /* Non-nil means generate motion events for mouse motion.
 12852 The special values `dragging' and `dropping' assert that the mouse
 12853 cursor retains its appearance during mouse motion.  Any non-nil value
 12854 but `dropping' or `drag-source' asserts that motion events always
 12855 relate to the frame where the mouse movement started.  The value
 12856 `dropping' asserts that motion events relate to the frame where the
 12857 mouse cursor is seen when generating the event.  If there's no such
 12858 frame, such motion events relate to the frame where the mouse movement
 12859 started.  The value `drag-source' is like `dropping', but the
 12860 `posn-window' will be nil in mouse position lists inside mouse
 12861 movement events if there is no frame directly visible underneath the
 12862 mouse pointer.  */);
 12863   DEFVAR_KBOARD ("system-key-alist", Vsystem_key_alist,
 12864                  doc: /* Alist of system-specific X windows key symbols.
 12865 Each element should have the form (N . SYMBOL) where N is the
 12866 numeric keysym code (sans the \"system-specific\" bit 1<<28)
 12867 and SYMBOL is its name.
 12868 
 12869 `system-key-alist' has a separate binding for each terminal device.
 12870 See Info node `(elisp)Multiple Terminals'.  */);
 12871 
 12872   DEFVAR_KBOARD ("local-function-key-map", Vlocal_function_key_map,
 12873                  doc: /* Keymap that translates key sequences to key sequences during input.
 12874 This is used mainly for mapping key sequences into some preferred
 12875 key events (symbols).
 12876 
 12877 The `read-key-sequence' function replaces any subsequence bound by
 12878 `local-function-key-map' with its binding.  More precisely, when the
 12879 active keymaps have no binding for the current key sequence but
 12880 `local-function-key-map' binds a suffix of the sequence to a vector or
 12881 string, `read-key-sequence' replaces the matching suffix with its
 12882 binding, and continues with the new sequence.
 12883 
 12884 If the binding is a function, it is called with one argument (the prompt)
 12885 and its return value (a key sequence) is used.
 12886 
 12887 The events that come from bindings in `local-function-key-map' are not
 12888 themselves looked up in `local-function-key-map'.
 12889 
 12890 For example, suppose `local-function-key-map' binds `ESC O P' to [f1].
 12891 Typing `ESC O P' to `read-key-sequence' would return [f1].  Typing
 12892 `C-x ESC O P' would return [?\\C-x f1].  If [f1] were a prefix key,
 12893 typing `ESC O P x' would return [f1 x].
 12894 
 12895 `local-function-key-map' has a separate binding for each terminal
 12896 device.  See Info node `(elisp)Multiple Terminals'.  If you need to
 12897 define a binding on all terminals, change `function-key-map'
 12898 instead.  Initially, `local-function-key-map' is an empty keymap that
 12899 has `function-key-map' as its parent on all terminal devices.  */);
 12900 
 12901   DEFVAR_KBOARD ("input-decode-map", Vinput_decode_map,
 12902                  doc: /* Keymap that decodes input escape sequences.
 12903 This is used mainly for mapping ASCII function key sequences into
 12904 real Emacs function key events (symbols).
 12905 
 12906 The `read-key-sequence' function replaces any subsequence bound by
 12907 `input-decode-map' with its binding.  Contrary to `function-key-map',
 12908 this map applies its rebinding regardless of the presence of an ordinary
 12909 binding.  So it is more like `key-translation-map' except that it applies
 12910 before `function-key-map' rather than after.
 12911 
 12912 If the binding is a function, it is called with one argument (the prompt)
 12913 and its return value (a key sequence) is used.
 12914 
 12915 The events that come from bindings in `input-decode-map' are not
 12916 themselves looked up in `input-decode-map'.  */);
 12917 
 12918   DEFVAR_LISP ("function-key-map", Vfunction_key_map,
 12919                doc: /* The parent keymap of all `local-function-key-map' instances.
 12920 Function key definitions that apply to all terminal devices should go
 12921 here.  If a mapping is defined in both the current
 12922 `local-function-key-map' binding and this variable, then the local
 12923 definition will take precedence.  */);
 12924   Vfunction_key_map = Fmake_sparse_keymap (Qnil);
 12925 
 12926   DEFVAR_LISP ("key-translation-map", Vkey_translation_map,
 12927                doc: /* Keymap of key translations that can override keymaps.
 12928 This keymap works like `input-decode-map', but comes after `function-key-map'.
 12929 Another difference is that it is global rather than terminal-local.  */);
 12930   Vkey_translation_map = Fmake_sparse_keymap (Qnil);
 12931 
 12932   DEFVAR_LISP ("delayed-warnings-list", Vdelayed_warnings_list,
 12933                doc: /* List of warnings to be displayed after this command.
 12934 Each element must be a list (TYPE MESSAGE [LEVEL [BUFFER-NAME]]),
 12935 as per the args of `display-warning' (which see).
 12936 If this variable is non-nil, `delayed-warnings-hook' will be run
 12937 immediately after running `post-command-hook'.  */);
 12938   Vdelayed_warnings_list = Qnil;
 12939 
 12940   DEFVAR_LISP ("timer-list", Vtimer_list,
 12941                doc: /* List of active absolute time timers in order of increasing time.  */);
 12942   Vtimer_list = Qnil;
 12943 
 12944   DEFVAR_LISP ("timer-idle-list", Vtimer_idle_list,
 12945                doc: /* List of active idle-time timers in order of increasing time.  */);
 12946   Vtimer_idle_list = Qnil;
 12947 
 12948   DEFVAR_LISP ("input-method-function", Vinput_method_function,
 12949                doc: /* If non-nil, the function that implements the current input method.
 12950 It's called with one argument, which must be a single-byte
 12951 character that was just read.  Any single-byte character is
 12952 acceptable, except the DEL character, codepoint 127 decimal, 177 octal.
 12953 Typically this function uses `read-event' to read additional events.
 12954 When it does so, it should first bind `input-method-function' to nil
 12955 so it will not be called recursively.
 12956 
 12957 The function should return a list of zero or more events
 12958 to be used as input.  If it wants to put back some events
 12959 to be reconsidered, separately, by the input method,
 12960 it can add them to the beginning of `unread-command-events'.
 12961 
 12962 The input method function can find in `input-method-previous-message'
 12963 the previous echo area message.
 12964 
 12965 The input method function should refer to the variables
 12966 `input-method-use-echo-area' and `input-method-exit-on-first-char'
 12967 for guidance on what to do.  */);
 12968   Vinput_method_function = Qlist;
 12969 
 12970   DEFVAR_LISP ("input-method-previous-message",
 12971                Vinput_method_previous_message,
 12972                doc: /* When `input-method-function' is called, hold the previous echo area message.
 12973 This variable exists because `read-event' clears the echo area
 12974 before running the input method.  It is nil if there was no message.  */);
 12975   Vinput_method_previous_message = Qnil;
 12976 
 12977   DEFVAR_LISP ("show-help-function", Vshow_help_function,
 12978                doc: /* If non-nil, the function that implements the display of help.
 12979 It's called with one argument, the help string to display.  */);
 12980   Vshow_help_function = Qnil;
 12981 
 12982   DEFVAR_LISP ("disable-point-adjustment", Vdisable_point_adjustment,
 12983                doc: /* If non-nil, suppress point adjustment after executing a command.
 12984 
 12985 After a command is executed, if point moved into a region that has
 12986 special properties (e.g. composition, display), Emacs adjusts point to
 12987 the boundary of the region.  But when a command leaves this variable at
 12988 a non-nil value (e.g., with a setq), this point adjustment is suppressed.
 12989 
 12990 This variable is set to nil before reading a command, and is checked
 12991 just after executing the command.  */);
 12992   Vdisable_point_adjustment = Qnil;
 12993 
 12994   DEFVAR_LISP ("global-disable-point-adjustment",
 12995                Vglobal_disable_point_adjustment,
 12996                doc: /* If non-nil, always suppress point adjustments.
 12997 
 12998 The default value is nil, in which case point adjustments are
 12999 suppressed only after special commands that leave
 13000 `disable-point-adjustment' (which see) at a non-nil value.  */);
 13001   Vglobal_disable_point_adjustment = Qnil;
 13002 
 13003   DEFVAR_LISP ("minibuffer-message-timeout", Vminibuffer_message_timeout,
 13004                doc: /* How long to display an echo-area message when the minibuffer is active.
 13005 If the value is a number, it should be specified in seconds.
 13006 If the value is not a number, such messages never time out.  */);
 13007   Vminibuffer_message_timeout = make_fixnum (2);
 13008 
 13009   DEFVAR_LISP ("throw-on-input", Vthrow_on_input,
 13010                doc: /* If non-nil, any keyboard input throws to this symbol.
 13011 The value of that variable is passed to `quit-flag' and later causes a
 13012 peculiar kind of quitting.  */);
 13013   Vthrow_on_input = Qnil;
 13014 
 13015   DEFVAR_LISP ("command-error-function", Vcommand_error_function,
 13016                doc: /* Function to output error messages.
 13017 Called with three arguments:
 13018 - the error data, a list of the form (SIGNALED-CONDITION . SIGNAL-DATA)
 13019   such as what `condition-case' would bind its variable to,
 13020 - the context (a string which normally goes at the start of the message),
 13021 - the Lisp function within which the error was signaled.
 13022 
 13023 For instance, to make error messages stand out more in the echo area,
 13024 you could say something like:
 13025 
 13026     (setq command-error-function
 13027           (lambda (data _ _)
 13028             (message "%s" (propertize (error-message-string data)
 13029                                       \\='face \\='error))))
 13030 
 13031 Also see `set-message-function' (which controls how non-error messages
 13032 are displayed).  */);
 13033   Vcommand_error_function = intern ("command-error-default-function");
 13034 
 13035   DEFVAR_LISP ("enable-disabled-menus-and-buttons",
 13036                Venable_disabled_menus_and_buttons,
 13037                doc: /* If non-nil, don't ignore events produced by disabled menu items and tool-bar.
 13038 
 13039 Help functions bind this to allow help on disabled menu items
 13040 and tool-bar buttons.  */);
 13041   Venable_disabled_menus_and_buttons = Qnil;
 13042 
 13043   DEFVAR_LISP ("select-active-regions",
 13044                Vselect_active_regions,
 13045                doc: /* If non-nil, any active region automatically sets the primary selection.
 13046 This variable only has an effect when Transient Mark mode is enabled.
 13047 
 13048 If the value is `only', only temporarily active regions (usually made
 13049 by mouse-dragging or shift-selection) set the window system's primary
 13050 selection.
 13051 
 13052 If this variable causes the region to be set as the primary selection,
 13053 `post-select-region-hook' is then run afterwards.  */);
 13054   Vselect_active_regions = Qt;
 13055 
 13056   DEFVAR_LISP ("saved-region-selection",
 13057                Vsaved_region_selection,
 13058                doc: /* Contents of active region prior to buffer modification.
 13059 If `select-active-regions' is non-nil, Emacs sets this to the
 13060 text in the region before modifying the buffer.  The next call to
 13061 the function `deactivate-mark' uses this to set the window selection.  */);
 13062   Vsaved_region_selection = Qnil;
 13063 
 13064   DEFVAR_LISP ("selection-inhibit-update-commands",
 13065                Vselection_inhibit_update_commands,
 13066                doc: /* List of commands which should not update the selection.
 13067 Normally, if `select-active-regions' is non-nil and the mark remains
 13068 active after a command (i.e. the mark was not deactivated), the Emacs
 13069 command loop sets the selection to the text in the region.  However,
 13070 if the command is in this list, the selection is not updated.  */);
 13071   Vselection_inhibit_update_commands
 13072     = list2 (Qhandle_switch_frame, Qhandle_select_window);
 13073 
 13074   DEFVAR_LISP ("debug-on-event",
 13075                Vdebug_on_event,
 13076                doc: /* Enter debugger on this event.
 13077 When Emacs receives the special event specified by this variable,
 13078 it will try to break into the debugger as soon as possible instead
 13079 of processing the event normally through `special-event-map'.
 13080 
 13081 Currently, the only supported values for this
 13082 variable are `sigusr1' and `sigusr2'.  */);
 13083   Vdebug_on_event = intern_c_string ("sigusr2");
 13084 
 13085   DEFVAR_BOOL ("attempt-stack-overflow-recovery",
 13086                attempt_stack_overflow_recovery,
 13087                doc: /* If non-nil, attempt to recover from C stack overflows.
 13088 This recovery is potentially unsafe and may lead to deadlocks or data
 13089 corruption, but it usually works and may preserve modified buffers
 13090 that would otherwise be lost.  If nil, treat stack overflow like any
 13091 other kind of crash or fatal error.  */);
 13092   attempt_stack_overflow_recovery = true;
 13093 
 13094   DEFVAR_BOOL ("attempt-orderly-shutdown-on-fatal-signal",
 13095                attempt_orderly_shutdown_on_fatal_signal,
 13096                doc: /* If non-nil, attempt orderly shutdown on fatal signals.
 13097 By default this variable is non-nil, and Emacs attempts to perform
 13098 an orderly shutdown when it catches a fatal signal (e.g., a crash).
 13099 The orderly shutdown includes an attempt to auto-save your unsaved edits
 13100 and other useful cleanups.  These cleanups are potentially unsafe and may
 13101 lead to deadlocks or data corruption, but it usually works and may
 13102 preserve data in modified buffers that would otherwise be lost.
 13103 If nil, Emacs crashes immediately in response to fatal signals.  */);
 13104   attempt_orderly_shutdown_on_fatal_signal = true;
 13105 
 13106   DEFVAR_LISP ("while-no-input-ignore-events",
 13107                Vwhile_no_input_ignore_events,
 13108                doc: /* Ignored events from `while-no-input'.
 13109 Events in this list do not count as pending input while running
 13110 `while-no-input' and do not cause any idle timers to get reset when they
 13111 occur.  */);
 13112   Vwhile_no_input_ignore_events = init_while_no_input_ignore_events ();
 13113 
 13114   DEFVAR_BOOL ("translate-upper-case-key-bindings",
 13115                translate_upper_case_key_bindings,
 13116                doc: /* If non-nil, interpret upper case keys as lower case (when applicable).
 13117 Emacs allows binding both upper and lower case key sequences to
 13118 commands.  However, if there is a lower case key sequence bound to a
 13119 command, and the user enters an upper case key sequence that is not
 13120 bound to a command, Emacs will use the lower case binding.  Setting
 13121 this variable to nil inhibits this behavior.  */);
 13122   translate_upper_case_key_bindings = true;
 13123 
 13124   DEFVAR_BOOL ("input-pending-p-filter-events",
 13125                input_pending_p_filter_events,
 13126                doc: /* If non-nil, `input-pending-p' ignores some input events.
 13127 If this variable is non-nil (the default), `input-pending-p' and
 13128 other similar functions ignore input events in `while-no-input-ignore-events'.
 13129 This flag may eventually be removed once this behavior is deemed safe.  */);
 13130   input_pending_p_filter_events = true;
 13131 
 13132   DEFVAR_BOOL ("mwheel-coalesce-scroll-events", mwheel_coalesce_scroll_events,
 13133                doc: /* Non-nil means send a wheel event only for scrolling at least one screen line.
 13134 Otherwise, a wheel event will be sent every time the mouse wheel is
 13135 moved.  */);
 13136   mwheel_coalesce_scroll_events = true;
 13137 
 13138   DEFVAR_LISP ("display-monitors-changed-functions", Vdisplay_monitors_changed_functions,
 13139     doc: /* Abnormal hook run when the monitor configuration changes.
 13140 This can happen if a monitor is rotated, moved, plugged in or removed
 13141 from a multi-monitor setup, if the primary monitor changes, or if the
 13142 resolution of a monitor changes.  The hook should accept a single
 13143 argument, which is the terminal on which the monitor configuration
 13144 changed.  */);
 13145   Vdisplay_monitors_changed_functions = Qnil;
 13146 
 13147   DEFVAR_BOOL ("inhibit--record-char",
 13148                inhibit_record_char,
 13149                doc: /* If non-nil, don't record input events.
 13150 This inhibits recording input events for the purposes of keyboard
 13151 macros, dribble file, and `recent-keys'.
 13152 Internal use only.  */);
 13153   inhibit_record_char = false;
 13154 
 13155   DEFVAR_BOOL ("record-all-keys", record_all_keys,
 13156                doc: /* Non-nil means record all keys you type.
 13157 When nil, the default, characters typed as part of passwords are
 13158 not recorded.  The non-nil value countermands `inhibit--record-char',
 13159 which see.  */);
 13160   record_all_keys = false;
 13161 
 13162   DEFVAR_LISP ("post-select-region-hook", Vpost_select_region_hook,
 13163     doc: /* Abnormal hook run after the region is selected.
 13164 This usually happens as a result of `select-active-regions'.  The hook
 13165 is called with one argument, the string that was selected.  */);;
 13166   Vpost_select_region_hook = Qnil;
 13167 
 13168   pdumper_do_now_and_after_load (syms_of_keyboard_for_pdumper);
 13169 }
 13170 
 13171 static void
 13172 syms_of_keyboard_for_pdumper (void)
 13173 {
 13174   /* Make sure input state is pristine when restoring from a dump.
 13175      init_keyboard() also resets some of these, but the duplication
 13176      doesn't hurt and makes sure that allocate_kboard and subsequent
 13177      early init functions see the environment they expect.  */
 13178 
 13179   PDUMPER_RESET_LV (pending_funcalls, Qnil);
 13180   PDUMPER_RESET_LV (unread_switch_frame, Qnil);
 13181   PDUMPER_RESET_LV (internal_last_event_frame, Qnil);
 13182   PDUMPER_RESET_LV (last_command_event, Qnil);
 13183   PDUMPER_RESET_LV (last_nonmenu_event, Qnil);
 13184   PDUMPER_RESET_LV (last_input_event, Qnil);
 13185   PDUMPER_RESET_LV (Vunread_command_events, Qnil);
 13186   PDUMPER_RESET_LV (Vunread_post_input_method_events, Qnil);
 13187   PDUMPER_RESET_LV (Vunread_input_method_events, Qnil);
 13188   PDUMPER_RESET_LV (Vthis_command, Qnil);
 13189   PDUMPER_RESET_LV (Vreal_this_command, Qnil);
 13190   PDUMPER_RESET_LV (Vthis_command_keys_shift_translated, Qnil);
 13191   PDUMPER_RESET_LV (Vthis_original_command, Qnil);
 13192   PDUMPER_RESET (num_input_keys, 0);
 13193   PDUMPER_RESET (num_nonmacro_input_events, 0);
 13194   PDUMPER_RESET_LV (Vlast_event_frame, Qnil);
 13195   PDUMPER_RESET_LV (Vdelayed_warnings_list, Qnil);
 13196 
 13197   /* Create the initial keyboard.  Qt means 'unset'.  */
 13198   eassert (initial_kboard == NULL);
 13199   initial_kboard = allocate_kboard (Qt);
 13200 }
 13201 
 13202 void
 13203 keys_of_keyboard (void)
 13204 {
 13205   initial_define_lispy_key (Vspecial_event_map, "delete-frame",
 13206                             "handle-delete-frame");
 13207 #ifdef HAVE_NTGUI
 13208   initial_define_lispy_key (Vspecial_event_map, "end-session",
 13209                             "kill-emacs");
 13210 #endif
 13211   initial_define_lispy_key (Vspecial_event_map, "ns-put-working-text",
 13212                             "ns-put-working-text");
 13213   initial_define_lispy_key (Vspecial_event_map, "ns-unput-working-text",
 13214                             "ns-unput-working-text");
 13215   /* Here we used to use `ignore-event' which would simple set prefix-arg to
 13216      current-prefix-arg, as is done in `handle-switch-frame'.
 13217      But `handle-switch-frame is not run from the special-map.
 13218      Commands from that map are run in a special way that automatically
 13219      preserves the prefix-arg.  Restoring the prefix arg here is not just
 13220      redundant but harmful:
 13221      - C-u C-x v =
 13222      - current-prefix-arg is set to non-nil, prefix-arg is set to nil.
 13223      - after the first prompt, the exit-minibuffer-hook is run which may
 13224        iconify a frame and thus push a `iconify-frame' event.
 13225      - after running exit-minibuffer-hook, current-prefix-arg is
 13226        restored to the non-nil value it had before the prompt.
 13227      - we enter the second prompt.
 13228        current-prefix-arg is non-nil, prefix-arg is nil.
 13229      - before running the first real event, we run the special iconify-frame
 13230        event, but we pass the `special' arg to command-execute so
 13231        current-prefix-arg and prefix-arg are left untouched.
 13232      - here we foolishly copy the non-nil current-prefix-arg to prefix-arg.
 13233      - the next key event will have a spuriously non-nil current-prefix-arg.  */
 13234   initial_define_lispy_key (Vspecial_event_map, "iconify-frame",
 13235                             "ignore");
 13236   initial_define_lispy_key (Vspecial_event_map, "make-frame-visible",
 13237                             "ignore");
 13238   /* Handling it at such a low-level causes read_key_sequence to get
 13239    * confused because it doesn't realize that the current_buffer was
 13240    * changed by read_char.
 13241    *
 13242    * initial_define_lispy_key (Vspecial_event_map, "select-window",
 13243    *                        "handle-select-window"); */
 13244   initial_define_lispy_key (Vspecial_event_map, "save-session",
 13245                             "handle-save-session");
 13246 
 13247 #ifdef HAVE_DBUS
 13248   /* Define a special event which is raised for dbus callback
 13249      functions.  */
 13250   initial_define_lispy_key (Vspecial_event_map, "dbus-event",
 13251                             "dbus-handle-event");
 13252 #endif
 13253 
 13254 #ifdef THREADS_ENABLED
 13255   /* Define a special event which is raised for thread signals.  */
 13256   initial_define_lispy_key (Vspecial_event_map, "thread-event",
 13257                             "thread-handle-event");
 13258 #endif
 13259 
 13260 #ifdef USE_FILE_NOTIFY
 13261   /* Define a special event which is raised for notification callback
 13262      functions.  */
 13263   initial_define_lispy_key (Vspecial_event_map, "file-notify",
 13264                             "file-notify-handle-event");
 13265 #endif /* USE_FILE_NOTIFY */
 13266 
 13267   initial_define_lispy_key (Vspecial_event_map, "config-changed-event",
 13268                             "ignore");
 13269 #if defined (WINDOWSNT)
 13270   initial_define_lispy_key (Vspecial_event_map, "language-change",
 13271                             "ignore");
 13272 #endif
 13273   initial_define_lispy_key (Vspecial_event_map, "focus-in",
 13274                             "handle-focus-in");
 13275   initial_define_lispy_key (Vspecial_event_map, "focus-out",
 13276                             "handle-focus-out");
 13277   initial_define_lispy_key (Vspecial_event_map, "move-frame",
 13278                             "handle-move-frame");
 13279 }
 13280 
 13281 /* Mark the pointers in the kboard objects.
 13282    Called by Fgarbage_collect.  */
 13283 void
 13284 mark_kboards (void)
 13285 {
 13286   for (KBOARD *kb = all_kboards; kb; kb = kb->next_kboard)
 13287     {
 13288       if (kb->kbd_macro_buffer)
 13289         mark_objects (kb->kbd_macro_buffer,
 13290                       kb->kbd_macro_ptr - kb->kbd_macro_buffer);
 13291       mark_object (KVAR (kb, Voverriding_terminal_local_map));
 13292       mark_object (KVAR (kb, Vlast_command));
 13293       mark_object (KVAR (kb, Vreal_last_command));
 13294       mark_object (KVAR (kb, Vkeyboard_translate_table));
 13295       mark_object (KVAR (kb, Vlast_repeatable_command));
 13296       mark_object (KVAR (kb, Vprefix_arg));
 13297       mark_object (KVAR (kb, Vlast_prefix_arg));
 13298       mark_object (KVAR (kb, kbd_queue));
 13299       mark_object (KVAR (kb, defining_kbd_macro));
 13300       mark_object (KVAR (kb, Vlast_kbd_macro));
 13301       mark_object (KVAR (kb, Vsystem_key_alist));
 13302       mark_object (KVAR (kb, system_key_syms));
 13303       mark_object (KVAR (kb, Vwindow_system));
 13304       mark_object (KVAR (kb, Vinput_decode_map));
 13305       mark_object (KVAR (kb, Vlocal_function_key_map));
 13306       mark_object (KVAR (kb, Vdefault_minibuffer_frame));
 13307       mark_object (KVAR (kb, echo_string));
 13308       mark_object (KVAR (kb, echo_prompt));
 13309     }
 13310 
 13311   for (union buffered_input_event *event = kbd_fetch_ptr;
 13312        event != kbd_store_ptr; event = next_kbd_event (event))
 13313     {
 13314       /* These two special event types have no Lisp_Objects to mark.  */
 13315       if (event->kind != SELECTION_REQUEST_EVENT
 13316 #ifndef HAVE_HAIKU
 13317           && event->kind != SELECTION_CLEAR_EVENT
 13318 #endif
 13319           )
 13320         {
 13321           mark_object (event->ie.x);
 13322           mark_object (event->ie.y);
 13323           mark_object (event->ie.frame_or_window);
 13324           mark_object (event->ie.arg);
 13325 
 13326           /* This should never be allocated for a single event, but
 13327              mark it anyway in the situation where the list of devices
 13328              changed but an event with an old device is still present
 13329              in the queue.  */
 13330           mark_object (event->ie.device);
 13331         }
 13332     }
 13333 }
/* [<][>][^][v][top][bottom][index][help] */
